Description: Yugoslavia refuses to clear war debris on Danube (downed bridges) unless financial aid for reconstruction is provided; European countries on Danube fear flooding due to winter ice dams will result. Diplomats decry environmental blackmail.

Headline: NATO targets water plants
Description: Water processing plants are targeted, among other structures, in an air attack on Yugoslavia during the Kosovo War.

Headline: Water pipeline in Zambia is bombed
Description: A water pipeline is bombed along the Great North Road in Lusaka, Zambia. No group claims responsibility for the attack, however the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola is suspected of placing the bomb. This attack coincides with four other area bombings on the same day.
Sources: Agence France-Presse (AFP) 1999; Associated Press (AP) 1999b; Mulenga 1999; National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 199902280003

Headline: Water for Lusaka, Zambia cut off by attack on water pipeline
Description: Bomb blast destroyed the main water pipeline, cutting off water for the city of Lusaka, population 3 million.

Headline: Bombs damage water, power, and Angolan Embassy in Lusaka
Description: Sixteen bombs are reported to have exploded throughout the city of Lusaka, Zambia, with damage targeted at water pipes, power lines, and the Angolan Embassy. At least one person is killed and two are injured. Many people are without water and power for many days after the explosions. No one claims responsibility for the bombs, however, it is speculated that the attackers were seeking to discredit the Zambian government by causing chaos.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; Mfula 1999

Headline: African nations fight over Zambezi island
Description: Namibia and Botswana engage in a territorial dispute over Sedudu Island, or Kasikili Island, in the Zambezi River, or Chobe River, related to the location of the border and access to water. The International Court of Justice rules in favor of Botswana in 1999.

Headline: Violent conflict in Afghanistan
Description: Violent conflicts break out over water resources in the villages Burna Legan and Taina Legan, Afghanistan and in other parts of the region, as drought depleted local resources.

Headline: Australian hacker causes sewage spills
Description: In Queensland, Australia, police arrest a man for using a computer and radio transmitter to take control of the Maroochy Shire wastewater system and release sewage into parks, rivers, and property.

Headline: Riots over privatization in Cochabamba, Bolivia
Description: Massive protests, riots, and violence result from efforts to privatize the water system of Cochabamba, Bolivia.

Headline: Riots in northern China
Description: Civil unrest erupts over use and allocation of water from Baiyang Lake, the largest natural lake in northern China. Several people die in riots by villagers in July 2000 in Shandong after officials cut off water supplies. In August 2000, six die when officials in the southern province of Guangdong blow up a water channel to prevent a neighboring county from diverting water.

Headline: Aqueduct in Colombia is attacked
Description: A bombing attempt occurs at an aqueduct in Colombia. The bomb does not detonate. The National Liberation Army is suspected in the attempt.
Sources: Agence France-Presse (AFP) 2000; National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200004110006

Headline: Water storage facility is destroyed
Description: Eritrea accuses Ethiopia of bombing the Red Sea port at Assab, saying several bombs are dropped on Assab, destroying a water storage facility on the outskirts of the town.

Headline: Ethiopian killed in water fight
Description: One man stabbed to death during fight over clean water during famine in Ethiopia.

Headline: Regional drought heightens tensions in Ethiopia and Kenya
Description: The Ethiopian government says that regional drought worsens traditional conflicts at watering points and over access to pasture. The tensions are heightened by the presence of the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF), an Ethiopian armed opposition group said to be operating from Kenyan territory near the common border.

Headline: French workers pollute river over labor dispute
Description: In July, workers at the Cellatex chemical plant in northern France dump 5,000 liters of sulfuric acid into a tributary of the Meuse River after they are denied workers' benefits. A French analyst points out that this is the first time "the environment and public health were made hostage in order to exert pressure, an unheard-of situation until now."

Headline: Water company is bombed to demand release of prisoners
Description: A water company office in Ustaritz, France is damaged by a bomb thought to be placed in support of a group called the Basque Fatherland and Freedom (aka ETA). The attackers leave writing on the wall in the building demanding the release of ETA prisoners.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Kenyans battle monkeys for drought relief
Description: A clash between villagers and thirsty monkeys leaves eight apes dead and ten villagers wounded. The duel starts after water tankers bring water to a drought-stricken area and monkeys desperate for water attack the villagers.

Headline: Students riot to protest water shortages
Description: Students riot to protest water shortages in Kenya.

Headline: Central Asian nations cut off water to neighbors
Description: Kyrgyzstan cuts off water to Kazakhstan until coal is delivered; Uzbekistan cuts off water to Kazakhstan for non-payment of debt.

Headline: Moroccan army destroys wells
Description: Units of the Moroccan army destroy the wells situated in the municipalities of Guelta and Boujdour. Citizens usually use these wells to provide water for their sheep in the summer.

Headline: Israeli settlers are accused of intentionally releasing sewage to contaminate Palestinian agricultural fields in the West Bank
Description: Israeli settlers from Efrat are blamed for deliberately releasing sewer water into Palestinian agricultural fields in the West Bank.

Headline: Settlers attack a village in Palestine, injuring civilians and cutting water supply
Description: In a village in Palestine, three Palestinians are injured by gunshots from Israeli settlers. The same settlers also cut the water supply to the village by damaging the pipes.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water supply tank for a condominium in Singapore deliberately contaminated
Description: A water supply tank is deliberately poisoned with kerosene and turpentine. Residents of the condominium complex in Singapore discover the contamination from the odor of their water.

Headline: Clashes between rioters and police over water shortages
Description: Sudanese rioters who are protesting against the failure of schools to reopen as well as water and electricity shortages clash with police who intervene to quell the riot. At least one student is killed and many are injured.

Headline: A man is arrested for attempted poisoning of community water supply in Turkey
Description: A man is arrested for attempted poisoning of the water supply for the village of Kurusaray, Turkey.

Headline: Terrorist drill gets out of hand in California
Description: A drill simulating a terrorist attack on the Nacimiento Dam in Monterey County, California got out of hand when two radio stations reported it as a real attack.

Headline: Luxury home burned to protest impact on watershed
Description: The Earth Liberation Front (ELF) claims responsibility for setting a luxury home under construction on fire. Their written statement says they targeted the home because of its location in the Lake Monroe watershed, a drinking water supply for the town of Bloomington, Indiana, which is in jeopardy from urban sprawl.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; Eco-Action 2003

Headline: US bombs Afghan powerhouse
Description: American forces bomb the hydroelectric facility at Kajaki Dam in Helmand province of Afghanistan, cutting off electricity for the city of Kandahar. The dam itself is not targeted.

Headline: Protests over water shortages
Description: Angry protests take place in various communities of Ain Berda province, Algeria over gas, water and electricity shortages. Youths build barricades and block roads during these demonstrations.

Headline: Chinese protestors block canal
Description: In an act to protest the destruction of fisheries from uncontrolled water pollution, fishermen in northern Jiaxing City, Zhejiang Province, dam a large industrial wastewater canal for 23 days. The wastewater discharges into the neighboring Shengze Town, Jiangsu Province, killing fish and threatening public health.

Headline: Two leaders of a water utility labor union assassinated
Description: The president of the Codazzi Waterworks Labor Union, Aldo Mejia Martinez, is shot and killed by five unidentified people. Six months later, his successor, Engeniano S?nchez D?az, is also murdered. The murders may be linked to a larger trend of homicides in Colombia of trade-union leaders and activists.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; Trade Union Confederation 2001

Headline: Taliban cuts off vital water supply to Iran
Description: During a 2001 drought, Taliban authorities cut off the flow of the Helmand River between Afghanistan and Sistan-Baluchestan, Iran, which relies on the Helmand as its only source of irrigation. The Iranian government allegedly responds by entering Afghanistan and building a series of diversion canals to restore flows. A 1973 water agreement between the two countries is never ratified and both Iran and Afghanistan have reported violations.

Headline: Palestinians destroy water supply to Israeli settlements
Description: Palestinians destroy water supply pipelines to the West Bank settlement of Yitzhar and to Kibbutz Kissufim. The Agbat Jabar refugee camp near Jericho disconnects from its water supply after Palestinians loot and damage local water pumps. Palestinians accuse Israel of destroying a water cistern, blocking water tanker deliveries, and attacking materials for a wastewater treatment project.
Sources: Israel Line 2001a; Israel Line 2001b; Environment News Service 2001

Headline: Deadly fight between Kenyan herders and farmers
Description: At least 130 people are killed in a string of clashes between Pokomo farmers and Orma, semi-nomadic cattle herders over access to land and river water.

Headline: Clashes between ethnic groups over access to water
Description: Clashes occur between Pokomo and Wordei ethnic groups over access to a water fresh source in Kenya.

Headline: Twenty people are killed over access to fresh water
Description: Twenty people total are killed in clashes between Orma and Pokomo ethnic groups over access to fresh water in Kenya.

Headline: Kyrgyzstan charges downstream countries for water
Description: In June 2001, the Kyrgyz parliament adopts a law classifying water as a commodity and announces that downstream countries would be charged for water. In response, Uzbekistan cuts off all deliveries of natural gas to Kyrgyzstan and accuses Kyrgyzstan of failing to honor an agreement to provide Uzbekistan with water in return for oil and gas.

Headline: Bombing disrupts Lebanese water supplies
Description: Water supplies to more than 20 towns are disrupted after a bomb explodes near the town of Baalbek in Lebanon.
Sources: FBIS 2001; National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200108270004

Headline: Water cut off in Macedonian conflict
Description: Water flow to Kumanovo (population 100,000), Macedonia cut off for 12 days in conflict between ethnic Albanians and Macedonian forces. Valves of Glaznja and Lipkovo Lakes damaged.

Headline: Fight over control of a water supply reservoir
Description: Macedonians and native Albanians in the border village of Radusa fight to control the water reservoir that supplies water to Skopje, the nation's capital.

Headline: Nepali soldiers stop rebels from targeting drinking water supplies
Description: According to the Nepal Defense Ministry, soldiers repulse attempts by rebels to blow up the sources of Kathmandu's drinking water supplies at Shivapuri and Sundarijal. No details of these incidents are given.

Headline: Unrest over shortages in Pakistan
Description: Civil unrest over severe water shortages caused by the long-term drought. Protests began in March and April and continued into summer. Riots, four bombs in Karachi (June 13), one death, 12 injuries, 30 arrests. Ethnic conflicts as some groups "accuse the government of favoring the populous Punjab province [over Sindh province] in water distribution.'

Headline: Philippine water poisoned
Description: The militant Islamist separatist group Abu Sayyaf threatens to poison the water supply in Isabela, a mainly Christian town on Basilan Island in the country's south. In October, residents in six nearby villages are suspected for contamination due to water that smelled like gasoline. Local officials respond by closing pipelines and bringing in drinking water by truck. In the months following the 9/11 attacks on New York, numerous false alarms of terrorist activity are reported around the world.
Sources: World Environment News 2001; Fenton Helm and Dutter 2001

Headline: A water tank car is destroyed by a landmine in Russia
Description: A water tank car is destroyed by a landmine in Grozny, Chechnya, Russia. A teenage girl is also wounded in the explosion.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200108140011

Headline: Residents riot over cut of water supplies
Description: Residents riot when city officials cut of water supplies to 1000 homes who are defunct on their payment. Police move in and disperse the crowd with rubber bullets.

Headline: Algerians riot over water shortages
Description: Algerians protesting against water shortages riot in the eastern coastal town of El Arrouch, Algeria, setting fire to buildings and vehicles.

Headline: Protesters clash with police over water shortages
Description: Clashes between protesters and police are reported in the east and south of Algeria, as well as in different neighborhoods of the capital, over water shortages. Streets are blocked and public buildings are burned.

Headline: Water shortages cause riots
Description: Power outages and water shortages cause multiple days of rioting in Rouached, Algeria. 11 people are injured. Riot police intervene.

Headline: Bolivian irrigators and townsmen clash over water rights
Description: Tarata, Bolivia experiences violent confrontations between irrigators from the region of Arbieto and residents of the nearby town of Tarata. The dispute centers on the allocation of water among these users and new water infrastructure that took water from the Laka Laka dam. In October, irrigators destroy approximately two kilometers of water supply pipeline. In response, residents destroy part of a primary irrigation channel. After failed negotiations, the water system is damaged again in December in another confrontation between irrigators and village residents.
Sources: Bustamante et al 2004, Moriarty Butterworth and van Koopen 2004

Headline: Botswana authorities destroy wells of Kalahari Bushmen
Description: Botswana's president Festus Mogae sends troops to the Kalahari Desert to destroy wells and empty water sources of indigenous Khoisan (also known as Bushmen), ostensibly in an effort to remove them from their ancestral lands and assimilate them into modern society. Critics blame the government of taking away water rights in favor of mining interests and labeled the government's actions a "siege"; Botswana is condemned by international observers. Against expectations, a band of Bushmen retreat into the desert and survive for years with little outside assistance.

Headline: Water company offices bombed in response to high tariffs for water
Description: Three explosions occur at the offices of a water company, Aquas Andinas of Chile. The explosions are attributed to a group called Pueblo Reagrupado. Pueblo Reagrupado is thought to have placed the bombs in response to high tariffs for water.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: "Unknown agent" released into water treatment plant in Colombia
Description: Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) releases an "unknown agent," presumably thought to be poisonous, in a water treatment plant. No injuries are reported.
Sources: Bogota Cambio 2002a; Bogota Cambio 2002b; Xinhua General News Service 2002; National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 200202230003

Headline: Drinking water in Libornia is poisoned
Description: Just one month after the poisoning of a water supply in another small town in Colombia, the water supply for the  town of Libornia is poisoned as well.

Headline: Drinking water poisoned in Pitalito
Description: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is accused of poisoning the town of Pitalito's water supply with heavy metals.

Headline: Bomb found in water pump station defused
Description: A bomb is found in a water supply pump station along a canal, however it is defused prior to causing any damage to the system. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is blamed for the attempted attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Gas line set on fire in a water treatment plant
Description: A gas pipeline in a water treatment plant is set on fire by "People's Militias" in Dosquebradas, Colombia. One death and two injuries are reported in association with the event.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water company sustains minor damages from bombing
Description: The chief engineer of a water company reports minor damage from a bomb placed near a reservoir in Bogota by the  Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Colombian rebels bomb dam
Description: Colombian rebels in January damage a gate valve in the dam that supplies most of Bogota's drinking water. Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) detonate an explosive device planted on a German-made gate valve located inside a tunnel in the Chingaza Dam.

Headline: Four wells found with human remains in Cote d'lvoire
Description: Conflict between the government of Laurent Gbagbo and opposing rebel forces leads to extensive violence and regional conflict. In late September 2002, there are reports of several mass graves discovered in the Bangolo. In Zeregbo and Bahably, four water wells are found with human remains. Early reports indicate that western rebel groups who captured the area killed the persons in the mass graves and wells between December 2002 and January 2003.

Headline: Youths destroy local water, electric, and telecommunication facilities in Cote d'lvoire
Description: On October 10, youths claiming to be members of the Group of Patriots for Peace (GPP) destroy facilities of the Ivoirian Water Distribution Company, the Ivoirian Electricity Company, and C?te d'Ivoire Telecommunications. Demonstrators say they were protesting the "free" supply of water, electricity, and telephone in rebel-controlled areas.

Headline: Bomb explodes in water utility office building
Description: A powerful bomb explodes in a water utility office building on the Island of Corsica. The building is also graffitied with the nationalist slogan "Freedom for Patriots."
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Deadly clash in Kashmir, India
Description: Two people are killed and 25 others injured in Kashmir when police fire at a group of villagers clashing over water sharing. The incident took place in Garend village in a dispute over sharing water from an irrigation stream.

Headline: Violence over Cauvery River in India
Description: Continuing violence over the allocation of the Kaveri River between Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. Riots, property destruction, more than 30 injuries, arrests through September and October.

Headline: Indian military protecting reservoir attacked by terrorists
Description: A camp of the Assam Rifles of the Indian military at Yairipok in Thoubal district with a mission to protect a water reservoir is attacked by suspected terrorists who fired grenades and other explosives on January 27. Later, a spokesman for the United National Liberation Front (UNLF) claims that the attack was carried out by its armed wing, the Manipur People's Army, which has been fighting for what it called an "Independent Manipur."

Headline: Italy foils terror plot
Description: Italian police arrest four Moroccans allegedly planning to contaminate the water supply system in Rome with a cyanide-based chemical, targeting buildings that included the United States embassy. Ties to Al-Queda are suggested.

Headline: Protests over the increase in water tariffs
Description: Protesters in Bamako, Mali protest the increase of water and power tariffs by the government.

Headline: Nepal rebels blow up powerhouse
Description: The Khumbuwan Liberation Front (KLF) blows up a 250 kilowatt hydroelectric powerhouse in Nepal's Bhojpur District, cutting off power to Bhojpur and surrounding areas. The damages take 6 months to repair and cost 10 million Rs (US $120,000). During 2002, Maoist rebels destroy more than seven micro-hydro projects, a water-supply intake, and supply pipelines to Khalanga in western Nepal.
Sources: Kathmandu Post, The 2002; Financial Times Global Water Report (FTGWR) 2002

Headline: Warehouse of drinking water project destroyed
Description: A rebel group, called the Communist Party of Nepal-Maoists, destroys a warehouse of the Bijauri Drinking Water Project in Nepal, including 30,000 meters of polythene pipes.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Multiple attacks on water towers
Description: Two water towers are blown up in Jango Ghari, a tribal area, where several other similar attacks have occurred. The power systems atop the towers are destroyed in the blast as well.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Plot to poison water and food supplies reported by Russian special forces
Description: A plot by Chechen rebels to poison water and food supplies in Groznyy, Russia, is reported by Russian special forces.

Headline: Water pipe destroyed by explosion
Description: A water pipe that had been planned for a new water supply system in Bujanovac is destroyed by an explosion. An Albanian group is thought be responsible for the bomb.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Inter-clan fighting of the Mudug region in Somalia occurs over resource scarcity
Description: January 2002. About 40 people are killed and 60 wounded in inter-clan fighting in the Mudug region of central Somalia. The violence is sparked by revenge killings over the deaths of eight fisherman, but a local elder, Muhammad Salad Du'ale, attributes the ongoing violence to the scarcity of water and grazing.

Headline: Far right-wing nationalists in South Africa plot to kill millions of black South Africans by poisoning water
Description: A major plot to kill millions of black South Africans living in the townships near Johannesburg is discovered by the South African National Intelligence Agency. The attackers are a group of far right-wing white South Africans. Their plans consist of contaminating water supplies by pouring an agricultural chemical into reservoirs that supply four townships.

Headline: Large protest over lack of free water
Description: Hundreds of residents and municipal union members protest the lack of free water in their town in South Africa.

Headline: Protests over insufficient free water
Description: Members and supporters of the ANC protest over insufficient free water and electricity in South Africa.

Headline: Colorado eco-terrorists threaten water supply
Description: Earth Liberation Front threatens the water supply for the town of Winter Park. Previously, this group claimed responsibility for the destruction of a ski lodge in Vail, Colorado that threatened lynx habitat.

Headline: Terrorist targets water systems
Description: Papers seized during the arrest of a Lebanese Imam at a mosque in Seattle include "instructions on poisoning water sources" from a London-based al Qaeda recruiter. The FBI issue a bulletin to computer security experts around the country indicating that al-Qaeda terrorists may have been studying American dams and water-supply systems in preparation for new attacks. "U.S. law enforcement and intelligence agencies have received indications that al-Qaeda members have sought information on Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems available on multiple SCADA-related Web sites,' reads the bulletin, according to SecurityFocus. "They specifically sought information on water supply and wastewater management practices in the U.S. and abroad."

Headline: Residents block highways over lack of drinking water
Description: A major cold wave and lack of electricity, gas, and drinking water has led residents of Ain Mlila, Algeria to block major highways until their demands are met.

Headline: Riots start over the cut off of drinking water
Description: Israeli warplanes hit water supply wells, pipelines, and wastewater treatment plants servicing hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in the Gaza region. Palestinian officials state that the attacks intentionally targeted the infrastructure, amounting to a war crime under the Geneva Protocol.

Headline: Residents barricade the municipality over better water infrastructure
Description: In early February, Ain Defla (Algeria) residents barricade the municipality and block access to the union and its associates. They demand better transport, water and educational infrastructure.

Headline: Riots over lack of water services
Description: Rioters in Algeria armed with knives and molotov cocktails set fire to government buildings. They are angered due to lack of electrical and water services.

Headline: Armed cadres kill Bangladesh Nationalist Party workers over resource dispute
Description: Suspected armed cadres of the Purbo Banglar Communist Party (PBCP) kill six Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) workers at Naidighee village in Naogaon, on April 25. According to police sources, the incident appears to be a continuation of a long-standing dispute over nine government water reservoirs and khas (farming) land in the village.

Headline: A man poisons a drinking water reservoir in Henan Province, China, sickening more than 60 people, in order to boost sales of his
Description: A man who sells water purifiers poisons a reservoir in Ruyang County, Henan Province, China, sickening at least 64 people. The man claims that he wanted to improve sales of his product.

Headline: Columbian water plant bombed
Description: A bomb blast at the Cali Drinking Water Treatment Plant kills 3 workers May 8th. The workers were members of a trade union involved in intense negotiations over privatization of the water system.

Headline: In attempt to prevent natural resource extraction, intentional oil spill leaves 4700 families without drinking water
Description: A controversial pipeline is attacked once again, causing oil to spill into a local stream, polluting the water supply used by 4700 families. The Ca?o Lim?n?Cove?as oil pipeline has come under attack hundreds of times in an attempt by the local population to disrupt and halt natural resource extraction by multinational companies. One source reports that since the pipeline was built in 1985 it has been attacked 972 times.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; SourceWatch 2018

Headline: Group bombs a rural water supply office and other offices
Description: A rural water supply office building is blown up along with other offices, in Parkal, India.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Iraqi water treatment plant damaged
Description: The Abu Nawas pumping station on the Tigris River, which supplies water to Sadr City and other treatment plants in Baghdad, is severely damaged during the 2003 conflict.
Sources: International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) 2009

Headline: Bomb explosion breaks water main, forcing water supply shutoff to Baghdad
Description: A bomb placed near a water main line explodes, breaking the pipe and forcing engineers to shut off the water supply to the entire city of Baghdad, Iraq. Major flooding in the surrounding neighborhood is caused as well.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) 2003

Headline: Insurgents bomb Iraq pipeline
Description: Insurgents bomb a main water pipeline in Baghdad. City engineers say this is the first strike against Baghdad's water system during the Iraq War, which began in March 2003. The bombing occurs around seven in the morning, when a blue Volkswagen Passat stops on an overpass near the Nidaa mosque and an explosive is fired at the six-foot-wide water main in the northern part of Baghdad, said Hayder Muhammad, the chief engineer for the city's water treatment plants.

Headline: Water systems damaged in US-Iraq war
Description: During the US-led invasion of Iraq, water systems are reportedly damaged or destroyed by different parties, and major dams are military objectives of the US forces. Damage directly attributable to the war includes vast segments of the water distribution system and the Baghdad water system, damaged by a missile.

Headline: Bomb found in water supply facility safely defused
Description: A bomb is defused at a water supply facility in Keady, Ireland. The facility supplies about 10,000 homes with water. A group called the Continuity Irish Republican Army (CIRA) is suspected to be responsible for placing the bomb.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water bottles are intentionally contaminated in 20 different Italian cities, sickening more than 50 people
Description: Around 50 people are sickened by water contaminated with either bleach acetone or ammonia in more than 20 different cities from across Italy. Authorities blame a "saboteur" or "copy-cat saboteurs" for these poisonings.

Headline: Iraq attempts to poison water at US base
Description: Jordanian authorities arrest Iraqi agents in connection with a botched plot to poison the water supply that serves American troops in the eastern Jordanian desert near the border with Iraq. The scheme involved poisoning a water tank that supplies American soldiers at a military base in Khao, which lies in an arid region of the eastern frontier near the industrial town of Zarqa.

Headline: Students protest lack of water supply
Description: Students protest against poor conditions at Mombasa Polytechnic University in Kenya, including lack of water supply and proper sanitation. The protest leads to riots and police intervene.

Headline: Women block water access to a Naval base
Description: A group of women on canoes protest safeguards on oil standards by blocking water access to a naval base in the Niger Delta, Nigeria.

Headline: Main water pipeline is destroyed by grenades in the Philippines
Description: Two grenades destroy a water pipeline at a reservoir in Kidapawan, Philippines, disrupting water supply to approximately 100,000 residents. The Moro Islamic Liberation Front is accused of the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200303190005

Headline: Sa'ad and Dir clans fight over water and grazing in Somalia
Description: Two days of heavy fighting in Mudug region of Somalia leave at least 43 people dead and over 90 injured. The fighting breaks out between the Sa'ad, Habar Gedir subclan and the Dir, and is concentrated in and around the villages of Towfiq and Awle, some 200 km east of Galkayo. As with the 2002 events, the clashes are triggered by revenge killings but the ensuing escalation of violence is also attributed to disagreements over water and grazing in the area.

Headline: Al Qaeda threatens US water
Description: Al-Qaeda threatens U.S. water systems via call to a London-based, Saudi-owned magazine. The spokesman told the magazine that "al Qaeda [does not rule out] using sarin gas and poisoning drinking water in U.S. and Western cities."
Sources: Associated Press (AP) 2003a; Waterman 2003; Washington Times, The 2003

Headline: Bombs found at US bottling plant
Description: Four incendiary devices are found in the pumping station of a Michigan water-bottling plant. The Earth Liberation Front (ELF) claims responsibility, accusing Ice Mountain Water Company of "stealing" water for profit. Ice Mountain is a subsidiary of Nestle Waters.

Headline: Sudan targets water in civil war
Description: The ongoing civil war in the Sudan has included violence against water resources. In 2003, villagers from around Tina said that bombings had destroyed water wells. In Khasan Basao they alleged that water wells were poisoned. In 2004, wells in Darfur were intentionally contaminated as part of a strategy of harassment against displaced populations.

Headline: Darfur war triggered in part by water
Description: The Darfur War is triggered in part by conflicts over the control of water and other natural resources.

Headline: Riots over water shortages
Description: Riots break out in the region due to unemployment, water shortages, and resentment of the government. Protesters attack town halls and other administrative buildings.

Headline: Taiwan to target China's water in defense?
Description: A 2004 Pentagon report on China's military capacity raises the concept of Taipei adopting military systems capable of being used as a tool for deterring Chinese military coercion by "presenting credible threats to China's urban population or high-value targets, such as the Three Gorges Dam." China promptly denounces "a U.S. suggestion' that Taiwan's Military target the Three Gorges dam, leading the US to deny that it had so urged.
Sources: China Daily 2004a; US Department of Defense 2004

Headline: Police kill dam protestor in China
Description: Tens of thousands of farmers stage a sit-in against the construction of the Pubugou dam on the Dadu River in Sichuan Province, China. Riot police are deployed to quell the unrest and one person is killed. Witnesses also report the deaths of a number of residents.

Headline: Government shuts off electricity and water supplies in northern Cote d'lvoire
Description: On November 4, the army carries out "Operation Dignity" and mounts surprise attacks on Bouake, stronghold of opposition forces and the largest city in the north, shattering an 18-month ceasefire. The Government cuts off electricity and water supplies to the north the day before the attacks. They remain off for about a week.

Headline: Riots over water shortage kill prisoners
Description: There are two incidents in early November at Abidjan's main jail, La Maison d'arr?t et de correction d'Abidjan (MACA) , in which prisoners are killed. The first incident is sparked by a lengthy water shortage; prisoners reportedly had not had water for 5 days except for small rations of drinking water. At least 7 prisoners die and 30 are injured in the ensuing riots. U.N. human rights officials said they were investigating the riot and could not give a final death toll.

Headline: Students riot over power cuts and water shortages.
Description: Students riot over power cuts and water shortages.

Headline: Police kill water protestors in India
Description: Four people are killed in October and more than 30 injured in November in ongoing protests by farmers over allocations of water from the Indira Ghandi Irrigation Canal in Sri Ganganagar district, which borders Pakistan. Authorities impose curfews on the towns of Gharsana, Raola and Anoopgarh.

Headline: Terrorists bomb water pipe in India
Description: Twelve Indian security forces are killed by an IED planted in an underground water pipe during "counter-insurgency operation in Khanabal area in Anantnag district.'

Headline: Four people employed by the water and sewage department kidnapped
Description: Three engineers and one contractor, employed by the city water and sewage board, are kidnapped in Kirkuk, Iraq. No reports could be found detailing the outcome of the kidnapping.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Missionaries working on a water project attacked
Description: Four Christian missionaries from the U.S. are killed and one other seriously wounded when they are attacked while working on a water project in Mosul, Iraq.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; Renaud and Johnson 2004

Headline: Driver killed while transporting water
Description: A driver of a truck transporting mineral water in Mosul, Iraq is killed when his truck is set on fire.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; Reuters 2004c

Headline: Riots in prison over water shortage
Description: Riots occur at the main prison in Abidjan over a water shortage.

Headline: Militia attack village over land and water disputes
Description: Boran militia attack Gabra village near the Ethiopian border. The attack is linked to long-running disputes over land and water.

Headline: Security staff of a public water system shot at while working
Description: Bullets are fired at the security staff of a public water pumping station in Kosovska Mitrovica, Kosovo. Authorities blame Albanian extremists for the attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Mexican farmers shot in duel over spring
Description: Two Mexican farmers argue for years over water rights to a small spring used to irrigate a small corn plot near the town of Pihuamo. In March, these farmers shoot each other dead.

Headline: Several government agencies related to water and other services attacked
Description: Over two months in 2004 in Nepal, the Communist Party of Nepal-Maoists bomb several government offices, including the Water Induced Calamities Control Sub-Division in Nadipur, Pokhara and the Groundwater Irrigation Project in Dang District.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Students protest over water shortages
Description: Students protest over water shortages.

Headline: Chinese engineers working on a dam are kidnapped, one is killed
Description: Two Chinese engineers working on a dam and a canal in Waziristan, Pakistan, are kidnapped by Pakistani militants seeking the release of six Pakistani comrades. During a rescue attempt, one of the two engineers is shot and killed, while the other is brought to safety.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; China Daily 2004b

Headline: Pakistan targets terrorists' water
Description: In military action aimed at Islamic terrorists, including Al Qaeda and the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, homes, schools, and water wells are damaged and destroyed in Pakistan.

Headline: US halts water projects in Gaza
Description: The United States halts two water development projects as punishment to the Palestinian Authority for their failure to find those responsible for a deadly attack on a US diplomatic convoy in October 2003.

Headline: Murusade and Duduble subclans clash over water well in Somalia
Description: Murusade subclan and Duduble subclan clash over a water well, with 23 fatalities. Separately, a dispute between the Dir and Marehan clans over control of water and grazing lands in Heraale leads to a death in October.
Sources: Puntland Development Research Centre (PDRC) 2014; The Somali Dir Clan's History: Codka Beesha Direed 2012; Salehyan et al 2014

Headline: Violent protests in South Africa
Description: Poor delivery of water and sanitation services in Phumelela Township leads to several months of protests. No one is killed during the protests, but a few people are seriously injured, and municipal property is damaged.

Headline: Protesters blockade a road over installation of pre-paid water meters
Description: Members of the Soweto Electricity Crisis Committee blockade a road in their city in protest of the installation of pre-paid water meters in their homes. Police use stun-guns to disperse them.

Headline: Rebels destroy offices of local water utility
Description: Rebels destroy several houses and the offices of the local police and water utility.

Headline: Militias smash water wells
Description: Janjaweed militias smash water wells and burn both food and seeds in the Jebel Marra area. They also allegedly throw dead bodies into some open wells.

Headline: Violent clashes triggered over a hydroelectric project in Ecuador
Description: A small community, San Pablo de Amali, in Bolivar province, Ecuador, resists a hydroelectric project on the local Dulcepamba River. The resistance by the community is generally peaceful, but some community members are arrested for acts of sabotage and destruction. In support of the developer, Hidrotambo S.A., the national government sends troops to the community on several instances, resulting in violent clashes. In 2012 the developer initiates construction. In 2015, the community claims that this construction causes severe flooding during a rain event, killing three local people, and destroying seven houses and 10 hectares of crop land. Judicial trials of community members are ongoing in 2019.
Sources: Carson 2019, Staberock and Lahidji 2016; Environmental Justice Atlas 2019; Observatorio del Cambio Rural n.d.; Calvopi?a 2016

Headline: Violence over water in Ethiopia
Description: At least 250 people killed and many more injured in clashes over water wells and pastoral lands. Villagers call it the "War of the Well" and describe "well warlords, well widows, and well warriors." A three-year drought has led to extensive violence over limited water resources, worsened by the lack of effective government and central planning.
Sources: British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) 2004; Associated Press (AP) 2005; Wax 2006

Headline: Bomb destroys power source for local water system
Description: A bomb explodes in the Margegaj village of Tropoj? District in Albania, destroying a power source for the local water system. Several villages are left without water.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: A mortar round hits a water facility
Description: A mortar round hits a water facility in Baghdad, Iraq, resulting in a disruption of water supply to residents serviced by the facility. No one claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200507010006

Headline: Gunmen attack civilians working on a water project
Description: Gunmen attack civilians working on a water project in Al-Faris, Iraq, killing 18 and wounding 22. No group claims responsibility for the shooting.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200507260001

Headline: Bomb placed at a water station explodes prematurely and kills both attackers
Description: A bomb at a water station explodes prematurely, killing the two men placing the bomb.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Car bomb near water services director kills one
Description: A car bomb placed near the Kirkuk city water services director detonates, killing one person and injuring at least 17 others in Kirkuk, Iraq.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Gunman take out electric lines, disrupting water service in Baghdad
Description: Electric lines that provide power for water supply services in Baghdad, Iraq are shot down by a gunman, causing a disruption to water services. These same power lines had been recently fixed after suffering from a similar attack in the months prior.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Power station damaged, taking down some of Baghdad's water distribution system
Description: A power station in Tarmiyah, Iraq is damaged by a fire, disabling a portion of Baghdad's water distribution system.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Six employees of a water utility found murdered inside the water treatment plant
Description: Six employees of a water utility in Baghdad are found murdered inside a water treatment plant. The actual date of their deaths is not known.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Three Iraqis killed while driving water to an army base
Description: A group of three Iraqi men are shot and killed while transporting water to a military base near Taji, Iraq.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water pipeline attacked with bomb
Description: A bomb placed near a water pipeline explodes, causing it to break. That same day, two nearby oil pipelines are also attacked.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water pipeline targeted in attack in Baghdad
Description: A water pipeline is damaged by a targeted explosion, disrupting water services to approximately two million people in Baghdad, Iraq.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; New Humanitarian, The 2005

Headline: Rocket lands near an Israeli national water company facility
Description: In one of two incidents in Israel on this day (cf. 200512120003), a Qassam rocket lands near a facility belonging to the Israeli national water company, Mekorot, in the western Negev desert. There are no injuries or damages resulting from the strike.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200512120004

Headline: Over 90 dead in Kenya water fight
Description: Police are sent to the northwestern part of Kenya to control a major violent dispute between Kikuyu and Maasai groups over water. More than 20 people are killed in fighting in January. By July, the death toll exceeds 90, principally in the rural center of Turbi. The tensions arise over grazing and water. Maasai herdsmen accuse a local Kikuyu politician of diverting a river to irrigate his farm, depriving downstream livestock. Fighting displaces more than 2000 villagers and reflects tensions between nomadic and settled communities.

Headline: Communist party in Nepal destroys a drinking water project
Description: The Communist Party of Nepal-Maoists destroys a drinking water project in the District of Arghakhanchi, Nepal, disrupting water service to thousands of people.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Marehan and Garre clans clash over land and water rights in Somalia
Description: The Marehan and Garre clans clash over land and water rights, with 34 fatalities.

Headline: Soviet troops dynamite Ukrainian dam
Description: On April 13th the Kiev Hydropower Station on the Dnieper River receives a threat that 40 rail cars filled with explosives had been placed on a portion of levees holding back the reservoir.

Headline: Militants wound guards at a water supply company
Description: Militants from the Salafist Group for Call and Combat attack a guard station at a water supply company in Thenia, near Boumerd?s, Algeria. The two guards are wounded in the attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Dam protester executed in China
Description: Chinese authorities execute a man who took part in protests against the Pubugou dam in Sichuan province in 2004 (see China 2004 entry). Chen Tao is convicted of killing a policeman, but is executed before legal appeals are completed.

Headline: Water utility systems destroyed during conflict in Congo
Description: During the long-running conflict in the Congo, many water utility systems are attacked and destroyed. By 2006, the World Bank estimates that at least one-third of water utility installations have been looted and completely destroyed.

Headline: Violent water clashes in Somali Region
Description: At least 12 people die and over 20 are wounded in clashes over competition for water and pasture in the Somali border region.

Headline: Water clashes kill 40 in Kenya and Ethiopia
Description: At least 40 people die in Kenya and Ethiopia in continuing clashes over water, livestock, and grazing land. Fighting occurs in the southern Ethiopia in the region of Oromo and the northern Kenya Marsabit district.

Headline: 200 people attack home of Water Resource Minister
Description: A group of around 200 people attack the home residence of Kamlesh Kumar Singh, the Jharkhand Water Resources Minister, in Kamgarpur, Palamu District, India. The minister is not home during the attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Two bombs explode at a water collection point
Description: Two bombs detonate at a water collection point near a village in India. No one is injured from the explosions.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Gunmen blow up the pipes of a drinking water treatment plant running to the U.S. Ayn al-Asad base
Description: Gunmen blow up the pipes of a drinking water treatment plant running to the U.S. Ayn al-Asad base. Clashes rage between the gunmen and members of the plant's security, and are followed by explosions that lead to the destruction of the plant's water pumps and power generators. No group claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200604100025

Headline: Director of water project killed
Description: The director of the Baqubah water project, Husayn Ali Atiyah, is killed by gunmen. The attack is considered part of a larger effort to undermine the Iraqi reconstruction process.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Employee of Iraq's Ministry of Water Resources killed
Description: An employee of the Ministry of Water Resources in Iraq is killed by a gunman.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Explosive device aimed for water supply detonates early, killing two, wounding one
Description: An explosive device targeting a water main in Kirkuk, Iraq, detonates prematurely, killing two and injuring one of the attackers.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Government official killed
Description: A government official working with the water authority in Kirkuk, Iraq is killed.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Two water truck drivers killed
Description: The drivers of a water truck are killed in Baghdad, Iraq by a gunman while driving for work.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Unsuccessful targeting of water pipeline
Description: A water pipeline in Baghdad is targeted by an explosive device placed nearby. However, the explosion does not damage the pipeline.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Rocket attack damages a Mekorot water station, Israel
Description: Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) claims responsibility for a rocket attack, which is aimed at Ashkelon, Israel, but lands in an industrial area just south of Ashkelon, damaging a Mekorot water station, causing no injuries.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200602030011

Headline: Lebanon, Israel target water infrastructure in attacks
Description: Hezbollah rockets damage a wastewater plant in Israel. Israeli counter-attacks damage water systems throughout southern Lebanon, including tanks, pipes, pumping stations, and facilities along the Litani River.

Headline: Drinking water supply for thousands destroyed
Description: Several drinking water supply reservoirs and pipelines that provide water for more than 20,000 people are destroyed by explosives in the Narayan and Jajarkot areas of Nepal. The Communist Party of Nepal-Maoists is suspected to be responsible for the attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Suspected terrorists kill a water tanker driver
Description: Suspected terrorists shoot and kill a water tanker driver and his assistant in Dherdoni who supply water to security forces near the Afghan border in North Waziristan, Pakistan. No group claims responsibility for the attack, but the Taliban is blamed.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200604100009

Headline: Bomb explodes near water pump station
Description: A bomb explodes near a water pump station in Quetta, Pakistan. No one is injured in the explosion.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water and gas supplies disrupted by explosion
Description: Water and gas pipelines in Pir Koh, Pakistan are destroyed, disrupting the delivery of these supplies to nearby communities. The Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) takes responsibility for the explosion.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water tank drivers killed
Description: Two people driving a water tank in Pakistan are shot and killed. They had delivered water to security forces along the Afghan border.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water pipelines destroyed by rocket attacks and explosives
Description: Several attacks with rockets and other explosives on pipelines that supply water to a gas plant in Dera Bugti, Pakistan, disrupt gas production.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; Dawn 2006

Headline: Gas and water pipeline blown up by insurgents in Pakistan
Description: A gas line and water pipeline in the Pir Koh - Dera Bugti District is blown up by insurgents, resulting in the suspension of water and gas supply to adjacent areas.

Headline: Sri Lankan rebels cut water supplies
Description: A major battle between the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (Tamil Tigers, LTTE) and the Sri Lankan Armed Forces takes place in July and August 2006 around the watershed of the Mavil Aru (Mother River) in the Kallar area of Trincomalee district. The Mavil Aru, a tributary of the Mahaweli River, supplies water to 20,000 villagers in the eastern Sri Lanka. The sluice-gates of the waterway are captured and closed by the LTTE, cutting off water supplies and leading to a major operation against them by the Sri Lankan military. The armed forces launch air strikes with the aim of capturing the waterway and sluice-gates, which was achieved on August 11, 2006.
Sources: British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) 2006b; British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) 2006c; Gutierrez 2006

Headline: An explosion damages a water pipeline supplying water to parts of Sri Lanka's capital, Colombo and surrounding suburbs
Description: An explosion damages a water pipeline that supplies water to parts of Sri Lanka's capital, Colombo, and surrounding suburbs. Tens of thousands of homes are without potable water as a consequence.  No group  claims responsibility but the act of sabotage occurs shortly after the Sri Lankan government reinvokes anti-terrorism legislation.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200610120005

Headline: Bomb attached to police vehicle carrying water supplies injures three
Description: Three police officers are injured after a bomb explodes from underneath a water truck in Vavuniya District, Sri Lanka.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Sudanese anti-dam militia attacks school
Description: Militia of the Merowe Dam Militia Implementation Unit in the Sudan attack a gathering of villagers concerned about the community impacts of the dam at a school in Amri village, killing three farmers and injuring more than 50 others.

Headline: Armed clashes in Yemen
Description: Local media report a struggle between Hajja and Amran tribes over a well located between the two governorates in Yemen. According to news reports, armed clashes between the two sides force many families to leave their homes and migrate. News reports confirm that authorities had arrested 20 people in an attempt to stop the fighting.

Headline: Battles at Kajaki Dam, Afghanistan
Description: The Kajaki Dam has been the scene of major fighting between Taliban and NATO forces, mainly British and Dutch. The Taliban is attempting to make it impossible to work on reconstruction of the dam and power lines to boost output.

Headline: Two people wounded by bomb at local watering hole
Description: Two people are wounded when a bomb explodes at a local watering hole in Jijel, Algeria.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Australian man murdered in fight over water restrictions
Description: A 36-year-old Australian is charged with murder after killing a man during a fight over water restrictions in Sydney. A number of incidents have been reported following ten years of drought and water restrictions, leading scholars to suggest a "link between persistent urban water restrictions and civil unrest."

Headline: Conflicts in Burkina Faso
Description: Declining rainfall has led to growing fights between animal herders and farmers with competing needs. In August, 2007 people are forced to flee their homes by fighting in Zounweogo province.
Sources: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) 2007

Headline: Tampering in Toronto
Description: A Toronto man previously accused of attempted murder and illegal possession of explosives is charged with eight more counts of attempted murder after allegedly tampering with bottled water, which he injected with an unspecified liquid.

Headline: Bomb placed on water meter kills four police officers, while another under a car injures ten
Description: A bomb placed on a water meter in Cielo Gonzalez Villa, Neiva, Colombia detonates, killing four police officers. On the same day, another bomb placed under a car detonates in front of a building occupied by the local mayor, injuring ten people. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is suspected of the crimes.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018: Kraul 2007

Headline: Protestors block main road in response to water diversion in Egypt
Description: In 2007 and 2008, shortages of drinking water provoke demonstrations in towns and villages in the Nile Delta: participants speak of a "Revolution of the Thirsty." Protestors block the main coastal road after the regional water company diverted water from farming and fishing towns to affluent resort communities. Riot police are sent to quell the disturbances.

Headline: A forced displacement campaign by the Ethiopian military includes destruction of water wells and other sources
Description: During a violent, forced displacement effort by the Ethiopian military, water wells and other water supply sources are destroyed. The Ethiopian military is seeking to move people out of the country side and into larger towns and cities in order to continue their counterinsurgency fight against the Ogaden National Liberation Front. Numerous sources report executions of those who refuse to cooperate.

Headline: Soldiers threaten to throw woman into a well and drown her if she does not comply
Description: A 20-year-old woman reports that prior to being beat by military forces, she was threatened with drowning in a well if she does not comply. This report is associated with reports soldiers guarding water holes and of other human rights abuses by the Ethiopian military from their campaign to defeat the Ogaden National Liberation Front.

Headline: Injuries at protest in Orissa, India
Description: Thousands of farmers breach security and storm the area of Hirakud dam to protest allocation of water to industry. Minor injuries are reported during the conflict between the farmers and police.

Headline: Bloody fight at a water filtering station leaves at least 33 dead
Description: An attack on a water-filtering station in the Al-Khalis District of Diyala Governorate in Iraq is thwarted by the Iraqi military and other forces, leaving at least 33 of the attackers dead. The number of deaths on the Iraqi side is not reported.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Director-general of water projects killed by gunmen
Description: The director-general of water projects in Badush, Iraq is shot and killed by gunmen.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Mortar fired at water treatment plant
Description: A mortar is fired at a water treatment plant in Baghdad, Iraq. No casualties are reported.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Tigris River polluted after bomb strikes oil pipeline
Description: The Tigris River is polluted with oil after a bomb strikes a pipeline near Baiji, Iraq. The river supplies drinking water for nearby communities.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Workers constructing water pipe attacked; two killed
Description: A bomb placed along a road kills two workers and wounds five others as they lay water pipes in Tal Afar, Iraq.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Workers fixing a water pipe killed
Description: Two workers fixing a water pipe in Baghdad, Iraq, are killed in an event that is reported as either a drive-by shooting or a bomb explosion. The pipeline was being fixed from an attack a month earlier.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Water pipeline and gas pipeline damaged by explosion
Description: Water supply is disrupted when a water pipeline and nearby gas pipeline are blown up in Pakistan.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Israel's sanctions against Gaza cause water shortages
Description: Israel's sanctions against Gaza cause water shortages and a growing public health risk. In particular, restrictions on fuel, spare parts, and maintenance equipment threaten the functioning of Gaza's already limited water and sanitation system.

Headline: Violent protests against the Kajbar Dam in Sudan
Description: Angry villagers in the Sudan stage protests against Kajbar Dam; four villagers are killed by government militia.

Headline: Water distribution facility warehouse burnt down
Description: A warehouse of a water distribution facility is burnt down in Yala Province, Thailand. Islamic insurgents seeking independence from Thailand are the suspected arsonists.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: A review of violence in Guatemala identifies more than 60 environmental activists killed and other instances of violence between
Description: Research by a professor at the University of Regina, Canada, finds that between 2007 and 2017 at least 61 Guatemalan activists were murdered for their work protecting rivers, lands, and the people who depend on them for their livelihoods.

Headline: Unknown militants fire at an aid agency's water tanker
Description: Unknown militants fire mortars at an aid agency's water tanker, then kill the driver and steal his tanker in an undisclosed location in eastern Afghanistan. No property damage is reported and no one claims responsibility for the incident.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200805200002

Headline: Assailants set fire to two water tanker trucks in Muqur, Badghis, Afghanistan
Description: Assailants set fire to two water tanker trucks in Muqur, Badghis, Afghanistan, killing one driver, wounding two others and destroying the two trucks. No group claims responsibility, although the Taliban is widely believed to be responsible.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200806110020

Headline: Driver of a water tanker truck killed
Description: A driver of a water tanker truck owned by an aid agency is killed while driving. Local officials place blame on Taliban militants.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: China cracks down on Tibet
Description: China launches a political crackdown in Tibet. At least some observers have noted the importance of Tibet for the water resources of China, though the political complications between Tibet and China extend far beyond water. As noted: "Tibet is referred to in some circles as the "world's water tower' ; the Tibetan plateau is home to vast reserves of glaciated water, the sources of 10 of the largest rivers in Asia, including the Yellow, Yangtze, Mekong, Brahmaputra, Salween, Hindus and Sutlej among others. By some estimates, the Tibetan plateau is the source of fresh water for fully a quarter of the world's population."

Headline: Multiple civilians killed by remotely-triggered bombs targeting water trucks
Description: At least two water trucks being used to deliver supplies to the Ethiopian army are targeted by remotely-triggered bombs. At least four civilians are killed and another eight are injured.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Iraqi water station destroyed
Description: A water station under construction is destroyed in an attack by an unidentified gunman. Explosives are also placed on the road near the project, injuring one person. The station was going to provide potable water to four villages that were at a distance from the Tigris River, east of Dalouiya.

Headline: Militants blow up a section of a water pipeline
Description: Militants blow up a section of a water pipeline in Baghdad, Iraq. The explosion tears an 18-inch hole in the pipe that carries drinking water to Baghdad's Adhamiyah, Rusafa, and Karrada districts. No casualties are reported and no group claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200810300021

Headline: Four killed in Kenya over dispute over boreholes
Description: Fighting over boreholes in arid northern Kenya kills at least four people as competition for resources grows in the drought-hit region between the Murulle and Garre clans in El Wak, Mandera District.

Headline: Confrontations occur along border of Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan over water resources
Description: Disputes over unclear borders and poor communications lead to a series of confrontations over water resources in a border area of Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. The confrontations with Kyrgyz border guards occur when villagers from Isfara Tajikistan cross into the southern Batken district of Kyrgyzstan to remove a dam blocking an irrigation canal preventing water from reaching the Tajik village of Hoja Alo. The dam is located in an area where the boundary line between the two states has not been agreed. Actions by Kyrgyzstan cut off irrigation water to Tajikistan during the spring growing season.

Headline: Security forces open fire on water privatization protesters in Mali
Description: One person is killed and five injured when security forces open fire on protests over an attempt to privatize water services in Lere, northwestern Mali.

Headline: Bomb detonates in front of drinking water office
Description: Unidentified persons detonate a socket bomb in front of the drinking water office in Tripureshwor. No casualties or damage are reported, and no group claims responsibility.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200804050020

Headline: Violent protests in Nigeria
Description: A protest over the price of water in Nyanya, Abuja, Nigeria results in violence, including the beating of water vendors.

Headline: Explosive device detonates destroying a tube well in Pakistan
Description: At Kachhi canal project in Lund Nullah near Sui, Balochistan Province, Pakistan, unknown assailants detonate an explosive device destroying a tube well. No casualties or motive are reported. No group claims responsibility.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200804190021

Headline: Taliban threatens water supply
Description: In October, the Taliban threatens to blow up Warsak Dam, the main water supply for Peshawar, during a government offensive in the region.

Headline: A local community takes control of dam outlet to prevent loss of water supply
Description: Over 100 villagers and farmers from the local community near Lake Paron in Peru use force to remove employees and take over the outlet controls of the lake after the lake had been drained by nearly 50% by the operator of the controls, a subsidiary of Duke Energy International, for hydropower operations.

Headline: Riots break out in Somaliland when water drilling rig is removed
Description: Riots break out after a water drilling rig that had been drilling water wells for one community in the capital is transferred by government authorities to the western part of the country. Five people died and fifteen are wounded in the demonstration.

Headline: Water aid workers kidnapped
Description: Five aid workers, employed by the charity Water for Life, are kidnapped at gunpoint in Somalia. This is one of the first instances of Somali natives being kidnapped, as well as one of the first instances of a woman being kidnapped.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018; New Humanitarian, The 2008

Headline: Unknown gunmen kidnap four Sudanese government drivers of the state water corporation
Description: Unknown gunmen kidnap four Sudanese government drivers of the state water corporation in Um Tajok, Darfur and steal a drilling rig. It is not known if the kidnapped persons and drilling rig are returned.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200803200009

Headline: Assailants attempt to damage a water pump outside of a refugee camp in Darfur
Description: At the Hassa Hissa camp near Zalinjay, Gharb Darfur, Sudan, ten assailants attempt to damage a water pump outside of an internally displaced person (IDP) camp. The armed men open fire on the pump and set fire to the pump and five generators. The assailants fight with occupants of the camp, wounding one. No group claims responsibility, although it is widely believed the Janjaweed Militia is responsible.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200812010034

Headline: Water delivery pipelines destroyed in protest over water transfers
Description: Pipelines are destroyed in Yemen by locals protesting the extraction of water in Abyan for piping to Aden.

Headline: Water trucks contaminated with cyanide
Description: Water trucks supplying water to U.S. military forces in Afghanistan are contaminated with cyanide.

Headline: Assailants detonate an improvised explosive device targeting a civilian water truck
Description: On Sunday morning, in Marawara, Konar, Afghanistan, assailants detonate an improvised explosive device targeting a civilian water truck, wounding four civilians and damaging one truck. No group claims responsibility.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200903070013

Headline: A bomb placed at water station kills six, including five children, in Khost City, Afghanistan
Description: A remote control bomb placed at a water distribution station detonates, killing six, including five children, in Khost City, Afghanistan.

Headline: During kidnapping by Taliban, water tank destroyed
Description: A group of four employees of a construction company in Kunar province, Afghanistan are kidnapped by the Taliban. The kidnappers also destroy a water tank during the attack.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Energy and Water Department attacked by suicide bombers, killing six and injuring dozens
Description: Six civilians die and approximately 30 others are injured when two suicide bombers attack the building of the Energy and Water Department in Khost City, Afghanistan.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Bomb damages water treatment plant, leaving community without water
Description: A bomb planted at a water treatment plant explodes damaging the plant and wounding two police officers in Villavicencio, Colombia. The town is left without water supply.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Village attacked in Ethiopian water pipe conflict
Description: Ethiopian Somalis attack a Borana community in the Oromia region over ownership of a new borehole being drilled on the disputed border between them. Three people from the Oromia village of Kafa are killed and seven injured, and the entire community driven from their homes. The drilling rig is destroyed, as well.

Headline: Man killed in Mumbai protest over water cuts
Description: Police clash with hundreds of Mumbai residents protesting water cuts. One man is killed and a dozen others injured. Mumbai authorities are forced to ration supplies after the worst monsoon season in decades.

Headline: Drought and water inequities spark killings India
Description: A family in Madhya Pradesh state in India is killed by a small mob for illegally drawing water from a municipal pipe. Others run to collect water for themselves before the pipe runs out. Drought and inequality in water distribution lead to increasing conflict in the region. Indian media report more than 50 violent clashes in the state capital, Bhopal during May alone. Since January, 12 people are killed and even more injured.

Headline: An improvised explosive device attached to a water tanker explodes in Iraq
Description: An improvised explosive device attached to a water tanker in the al-Mahawii district of the Babel province explodes, wounding the driver. The blast causes severe damage to the tanker. No one claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200912110015

Headline: North Korea dam release kills six in South Korea
Description: Without previous warning, North Korea releases 40 million cubic meters of water from the Hwanggag dam, causing a flash flood on the Imjin River. In South Korea, at least 6 fisherman and campers are drowned. North Korea claims that the water had to be urgently released and promises to warn the South of future releases. South Korea fears that North Korea could use the water of the dam as a weapon during a violent conflict.

Headline: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan threaten to contaminate local water resources
Description: The Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) threatens to contaminate local water resources in a letter faxed to the Directorate of Military Lands and Cantonments in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. The letter stated that the TTP had procured 200 liters of a poisonous material that would be used to contaminate water sources and reservoirs in the wards falling under Rawalpindi Cantonment Board (RCB) and Chaklala Cantonment Board (CCB) limits unless the Army stopped military operations in South Waziristan.

Headline: Homemade bomb is planted inside the gates of the Metro Water District
Description: On Wednesday, ordnance experts defuse a homemade bomb discovered by employees  planted on a bench inside the gates of the Metro Water District, a government-run building at Cotabato, Philippines. No damage or casualties occur. No group claims of responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 200904290018

Headline: Police use ammunition against demonstrators protesting water shortages in Somaliland
Description: Police use live ammunition against demonstrators in the southern part of Hargeisa. Residents of Ahmed Dhagah district in Hargeisa, mostly women and children, take to the streets protesting severe water shortages.

Headline: One dead in South Yemen protest over water cuts
Description: At least one Yemeni is killed and three wounded in clashes with police in Aden in southern Yemen over the cutting off of water.

Headline: Hydroelectric construction company hires armed private security to quell local opposition in Guatemala
Description: In the Q'anjob'al and Chug Territory of northern Huehuetenango, Guatemala, three proposed hydroelectric projects supported by the national government incite strong local opposition. The hydroelectric construction company hires armed private security personnel to quell confrontations and acts of vandalism.

Headline: Bomb in water truck kills 3 in Afghanistan
Description: A remote-controlled bomb hidden in a water truck kills three people, including two children, in the eastern Afghan province of Khost, which borders Pakistan.

Headline: Army troops  locate and safely defuse three cylinder bombs  to be used against the town's aqueduct
Description: On Thursday, in a rural area of the municipality of Cajibio, Cauca, Colombia, Army troops from the 29th Brigade locate and safely defuse three cylinder bombs suspected to be planted by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia's (FARC) 6th Front. According to authorities, the explosives were going to be used against the town's aqueduct. No casualties or damages are reported and no group claims responsibility for the attempted bombing attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 201001280009

Headline: Guatemalans mine protestors shot
Description: Two unidentified gunmen on a motorbike shoot an activist protesting the impacts of mining on water quality and local water rights.

Headline: Violent water protest in India
Description: A protest about water shortages in the National Capital Territory of Delhi in India leads to violence. Erratic water supply and cutoffs in the Kondli area of Mayur Vihar in East Delhi causes a violent protest and several injuries.

Headline: Protestors killed and injured in
Description: At least three deaths and dozens of injuries are reported during protests over land and water given away for a power plant in Sompeta in Srikakulam district in Andhra Pradesh, India.

Headline: Militants blow up pump houses belonging to the Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL) and to the railways
Description: On Monday, in the Karrampada area of West Singbhum, Jharkhand, India, suspected Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-Maoist) militants blow up two pump houses, one belonging to the Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL) and the other to the railways. Water supply is affected in the area as a result of the attack. No casualties are reported.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019. ID. 201004190016

Headline: Unidentified militants detonate an improvised explosive device targeting a water tanker
