Description: Protests against the building of dams on the Brahmaputra River in India's Himalayan state of Arunachal Pradesh turns violent, leading to two deaths and additional injuries. Both China and India have put forward plans for nearly 150 dams in the region, with major local opposition.

Headline: Water shortage led to clashes between two groups in the parched Sehore district, India
Description: Water shortage led to clashes between two groups in the parched Sehore district, India leaving 7 people injured and one critical.

Headline: Bombs detonated at hydroelectric power plant in East Java
Description: Several explosive devices detonate at a hydroelectric power plant in Biltar, East Java, Indonesia.

Headline: Islamic State fighters destroy pipeline that provides water for eastern Mosul, Iraq
Description: Islamic State fighters cut electricity to pumping stations and destroy a pipeline that provides water for eastern Mosul, Iraq, leaving more than half a million people without water. The group has intentionally cut off water supplies to various neighborhoods, according to a Mosul City Council official responsible for supervising the city's water and energy services.

Headline: Islamic State militants raid Great Manmade River Project pumping station
Description: Around 60 Islamic State militants raid the Great Manmade River (GMR) project station in Ash Shwayrif, southwest of Sirte. This system provides water to the Libyan Sahara and the northern cities of Benghazi, Sirte, and Tripoli.

Headline: Water pipeline is damaged in Pakistan
Description: A water pipeline is damaged from explosions when it is misidentified as a gas pipeline, disrupting the water supply to a nearby village.

Headline: Public officials taken hostage after an oil spill polluted local waters
Description: An indigenous community in the Peruvian Amazon takes at least eight public officials hostage after an oil spill pollutes local water and lands. The Wampis community of Mayuriaga seizes the military helicopter and holds crew members and public officials in concern over inadequate emergency response plans.

Headline: Water wells attacked in Somalia
Description: Two wells are attacked by militia thought to be part of Al-Shaabab.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201605140030

Headline: Opposition leader killed after opposing threats to land and water
Description: Environmental activist and opposition leader Sikhosiphi Radebe in South Africa is murdered after opposing industrial mining development that threatened community water and land.

Headline: A severe drought sparked "water riots" in Northern KwaZulu-Natal
Description: A severe drought in Northern KwaZulu-Natal sparks 'water riots' in the town of Jozini over access to water and in opposition to the installation of water meters. Violence erupts after a community protest, leading to the arrest of 23 people.

Headline: Guard at water well in the Sudan is attacked
Description: A guard at water wells in the Um Burma area, Sudan is attacked and severely injured by paramilitaries.

Headline: Water pumping plant attacked in Syria
Description: A water pumping station is attacked by the Islamic State (IS) in Deir ez-Zor, Syria as part of numerous attacks that leave hundreds of people dead, including Syrian soldiers, IS militia, and civilians.
Sources: Latin American Herald Tribune (LAHT) 2016; National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201601160008

Headline: Attack by the Islamic State on Tishreen Dam on the Euphrates River
Description: Islamic State (IS) militants attack the Tishrin Dam on the Euphrates River in Syria. The attack is repelled with airstrikes. The following day a similar attack occurs during which at least 14 IS militants are killed.

Headline: Disruption of electrical system cuts power to water supply in Damascus, Syria
Description: Attacks on Syrian electricity transmission stations cut power needed for water pumping to the eastern and western parts of Damascus. Authorities temporarily restore power five days later, but new fighting again cuts water to the city.

Headline: Intentional attacks on water infrastructure
Description: Control over power and water infrastructure and intentional attacks on that infrastructure are being used as  weapons in the civil war in Syria. Officials estimate there has been a 50 percent reduction in access to safe water in the country since the war began.

Headline: Threats to cut off supply of water in northwestern Tunisia
Description: Residents of Fernana in northwestern Tunisia threaten to cut off the supply of water delivered by a pumping station to the capital, Tunis. They are protesting economic conditions and repeated water cuts that have sparked anger and protests among the local population. At least one death is reported. Water shortages are experienced in Sousse, Nabeul, Sfax, Kef, Siliana, Beja, Sidi Bouzid, Ben Arous, Medenine and Tataouine. Given the increasing number of protests, the Tunisian citizen's water observatory, Watchwater, warns against a possible "thirst uprising."

Headline: Water pipeline is bombed in Turkey
Description: A water pipeline is the target of an explosive device in Mardin, Turkey.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201604170038

Headline: Pumping station is attacked in the Russia-Ukraine conflict, interrupting the water supply for 1.5 million people
Description: A pumping station that is part of the Yuzhnodonbasskaya water pipeline is attacked. This pumping station provides water to 1.5 million people in the Donbas region, Ukraine.

Headline: Small dam is cyber attacked
Description: U.S. authorities discover that Iranian hackers have successfully infiltrated the control system of a small dam in New York State. Due to work being performed on the dam, the hackers are unable to alter dam operations, however the event exposes the risks of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure.

Headline: Massive opposition to project that threatens Indian heritage and water supplies
Description: Hundreds of people are injured and arrested at protests over the construction of a major oil pipeline that threatens water quality on and near Native American lands. Massive opposition to the project developed in 2016 when the planned route reached the site of a Native American tribe called the Standing Rock Sioux, who say the plans threaten their heritage and local water supplies.

Headline: Stand-off over water rights and use resulting in death
Description: In a standoff over water rights and land use, armed ranchers occupy a federal wildlife refuge in a protest that ends with one death and several arrests.

Headline: Rioting and looting over energy and water cuts in Venezuela
Description: Rioting and looting over energy and water cuts leaves fifteen people injured, as severe drought effects on hydropower generation worsen energy availability and economic disruptions. President Maduro blames the crisis on the fall in global oil prices, a drought that has affected hydroelectric power generation, and political factors.

Headline: Millions of people in Yemen deprived of access to clean water
Description: Attacks on water and power infrastructure throughout Yemen deprive nearly 20 million people of reliable access to clean water.

Headline: Air raids damage water project in Yemen
Description: An air raid causes damage to a water project in Razih District, Saada, Yemen.

Headline: Air raids damage wells in Yemen
Description: Five air raids leave wells damaged in Sirwah District, Marib, Yemen.

Description: The Al-Awadh dam is damaged in an air raid in Radman District, Bayda, Yemen.

Description: The Soqam dam in Sirwah District, Marib, Yemen, is damaged during air raids.

Description: Three water trucks are struck in air raids in Al-Mahabishah District, Hajjah, Yemen.

Description: Air raids damage two desalination plants in Al Mokha and At Ta'iziyah Districts, Taizz, Yemen.

Description: The Al-Qis water factory is struck during two air raids in, Al-Hawta District, Lahj, Yemen.

Description: A water pump in Kitaf Wa Al-Boqe'e District, Sa'ada, Yemen, is damaged in the ongoing sub-national conflict.

Description: A water tank and pump are damaged by air raids in Al-Safra'a and Haydan Districts, Saada, Yemen.

Description: Water tanks are hit during air raids in Khadir and Al-Mawasit Districts, Taizz, Yemen.

Description: A water tank project and a water tank are hit during air raids in Harib and Sirwah Districts, Marib, Yemen.

Description: A water well is damaged in Harf Sufyan District, Amran, Yemen, by an air raid.

Headline: Water well is damaged by air raid in Yemen
Description: A water well is damaged in Bilad Al-Rus District, Sanaa, Yemen by an air raid.

Headline: Dam and water driller are damaged by air raids in Yemen
Description: The Al-Aqran dam and a water driller are hit during ongoing air raids in Nihm District, Sanaa, Yemen.

Headline: Desalination company is hit by air raid in Yemen
Description: An early morning air raid causes damage to a desalination company in Al Mokha District, Taizz, Yemen.

Headline: Desalination plant is hit by air raids in Yemen
Description: A desalination plant is hit during multiple air raids in Al Mokha District, Taizz, Yemen.

Headline: Main water tank is damaged in Yemen
Description: In Hayfan District, Taizz, a communities main water tank is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Multiple attacks damage water tanks in Yemen
Description: Water tanks are damaged over the course of several days in Kamaran District, Hudaydah, Yemen.

Description: Several water pumps are hit during two air raids in Baqim District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Two dams are hit by air raids in Yemen
Description: The Al-Hayathim dam and the Mahalli dam were both struck during air raids in Nihm District, Sanaa, Yemen in early December.

Headline: Water driller is damaged by air raids in Yemen
Description: A water driller is damaged by ongoing air raids in Arhab District, Sanaa, Yemen.

Description: An air raid causes damage to a water driller in Sirwah District, Marib, Yemen.

Description: Four air raids cause damage to a water driller in Al-Safra'a District, Saada, Yemen.

Description: A water project is struck during an air raid in Kitaf Wa Al-Boqe'e District, Saada, Yemen.

Description: Water stations hit during air raids in Bila Al-Rus District, Sanaa, Yemen.

Description: A water tank in Bani Sa'ad District, Al Mahwit, Yemen is damaged by the ongoing conflict.

Description: A water tank is hit during three air raids in Al-Mahwit District, Al Mahwit, Yemen.

Headline: Water well is damaged by air raid
Description: In Nihm District, Sanaa, a water well is damaged by an air raid in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Water well is hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water well is hit during an air raid in Asilan District, Shabwa, Yemen.

Headline: From late 2016 through early 2017, the water supply in Damascus, Syria is periodically cut when springs outside city are attacked
Description: Up to four million people in Damascus suffer a loss of water services after springs outside the city are attacked. Water from the Wadi Barada and Ain al-Fija springs, which serve 70 percent of the Syrian capital, is cut off when water infrastructure is deliberately targeted.

Headline: Suspected Taliban militants blow up irrigation dam in Afghanistan
Description: Suspected Taliban militants blow up a dam storing water for irrigation in Shorabak, Kandahar, Afghanistan.

Headline: Road is blocked during protests over lack of access to water in Algeria
Description: Citizens of Grarem Gouga, Mila, Algeria block a road with barricades to demand more water supply, in protest of only receiving water every 15 days.

Headline: Residents of Babar, Algeria protest lack of water and sanitation infrastructure
Description: Residents of Babar, Khenchela, Algeria demonstrate to demand improvement of sanitation and drinking water infrastructure. The demonstrations include blocking roads with burning tires.

Headline: Citizens protesting water cuts shut down local government in Algeria
Description: Citizens protesting against water cuts shut down the local government, including the city hall, for several days in two cities in northern Algeria.

Headline: Protests over decreasing local drinking water supply
Description: Protestors from the city of Chetma, Biskra, Algeria block roads to protest against the decreasing local drinking water supply.

Headline: Clashes over the ecological impacts of a proposed coal plant on aquatic ecosystems and fisheries
Description: Protesters take to the streets in the center of Dhaka and more than 50 are injured in clashes over the potential ecological impacts of a proposed coal plant on aquatic ecosystems and fisheries. These actions follow on protests from 2016.

Headline: Protestors and police clash during march against water and electricity cutoffs
Description: A march is led by members of Bundu dia Kongo who are protesting the cut off of water and electricity services to their leaders' residence. Protestors and police clash, leading to injuries in both parties.

Headline: Bomb damages water truck in Egypt
Description: Islamic State fighters claim responsibility for bombs placed in a road that detonates, damaging a water truck and a tank in Sheikh Zuweid, North Sinai, Egypt.

Headline: Fighting over access to water between herdsmen and farmers
Description: Fighting is reported between youth and herdsmen over the alleged killing of a farmer by the herdsmen and the destruction of water sources used by their cattle.

Headline: Demonstration over access to clean water turns violent
Description: Demonstrations led by residents of Ketu South, Volta, Ghana, who are upset about the drying up of domestic groundwater wells, turn violent. Property is damaged and clashes between residents and police result in the death of one resident and the injury of two others.

Headline: Community demonstrator murdered while protesting local hydroelectric projects
Description: Don Sebastian Alonzo Juan, 72, is shot and killed while participating in a peaceful community demonstration in Yichkisis, village of San Mateo Ixtatan, Huehuetenango, Guatemala, against three local hydroelectric projects. The shots are reportedly fired by the private security guards hired by the hydroelectric project company.

Headline: Protests in Guinea over lack of water and electricity lead to violent clashes, killing three and injuring many
Description: Protests in Boke, Guinea about lack of water and electricity lead to clashes between police and protestors, leading to property damage, three dead, and 41 wounded.

Headline: Lack of water triggers violent protest in Guinea
Description: People protesting the lack of water supply are dispersed by police after some items are set on fire and access to a local highway is blocked in Matam, Conakry, Guinea.

Headline: Protests over cuts in water and power services turn violent in Guinea
Description: People protesting in Sangar?di, Boke, Guinea against cuts to water and power services are reported to have raided and attacked the gendarmerie, the police premises, and the residences of several individuals.

Headline: Violent clashes between youth and police over water and power cuts in Guinea
Description: Violent clashes break out between youth and police, causing injuries on both sides, including reports of two youths sustaining injuries from gunfire. The youth are protesting against power and water cuts in Sangar?di, Boke, Guinea.

Headline: Police kill five farmers during protests over water shortages in Madhya Pradesh, India
Description: Water shortages due to drought and mismanagement contribute to violent unrest of farmers in Madhya Pradesh, India. During one protest, police shoot into a crowd, killing five protestors.

Headline: Islamic State militants burn water purification plant in Iraq
Description: Militants from the Islamic State burn a water purification plant in a town north of the city of Mosul.

Headline: A bomb planted at water, oil, and gas pipelines explodes
Description: One of four bombs planted near water, gas, and oil pipelines explodes, injuring a policeman in Dibis, Kirkuk, Iraq.

Headline: Conflict over water quotas lead to two deaths in Iraq
Description: Conflict arises between two tribes over water quotas, leading to two deaths and eight injuries in Suq Al-Shoyokh, Thi-Qar, Iraq.

Headline: Islamic State is accused of cutting off water to a village by diverting a river
Description: A group identified as the Islamic State is accused of cutting off the water flow to a village by diverting a river in Abu Karmah, Muqdadiyah, Diyala, Iraq.

Headline: Three water authority employees are attacked in conflict over water well
Description: Three employees of a water authority agency in Ar Ramtha, Irbid, Jordan are shot at and assaulted during their attempt to prevent the drilling of a water well.

Headline: Al-Shabaab militants destroy water well in Kenya
Description: Al-Shabaab militants destroy an important water well that had been drilled by the Kenyan army in the town of Lafey, Mandera County, leaving hundreds of residents without water.

Headline: Water and land disputes between farmers and pastoralists leave one dead in Kenya
Description: One person is shot and killed after violence erupts between the farmer and herder communities in Kenya where water and land disputes are a driver of conflict.

Headline: Irrigation water pipe destroyed in Kenya by residents concerned over local access to water
Description: Residents of Nyeri Town, Nyeri, Kenya reportedly destroy an irrigation water pipe that is being run through their land for a neighboring community. The residents who caused the destruction are upset because they don't believe they would benefit from the project.

Headline: Water pumps destroyed in conflict over access to water in Mali
Description: People identified as militants destroy several water pumps and a number of fields and seize cattle in Kewa, Djenne, Mopti, Mali.

Headline: Two communities clash over water, leaving one dead
Description: A fight over water resources erupts in Oaxaca, Mexico, on May 17 between neighboring community members, leaving one dead, several injured, and numerous houses destroyed. The conflict began due to a disagreement between two communities, Ayutla and Tamazul?pam del Esp?ritu Santo, around which one has the right to a spring that provides potable water supplies.

Headline: Protest over shortages of drinking water turn violent in Morocco
Description: A protest in Zagora, Dr?a-Tafilalet, Morocco, over shortages of drinking water turns violent, resulting in 21 arrests, damage to property, and injuries to members of the security force.

Headline: Protests over inadequate water, food, and healthcare lead to 10 arrests in Nigeria
Description: Ten people who had been uprooted from their homes by Boko Haram are arrested when protesting for better water, food, and healthcare at their temporary camps in Konduga, Borno, Nigeria.

Headline: Israeli forces destroy water pipes in the West Bank
Description: Israeli forces destroy water pipes in a rural area, leading to clashes between Israeli forces and local Palestinians in Jenin, West Bank, Palestine.

Headline: Water well is poisoned in Somalia, killing more than 30 people
Description: Thirty-two people are reported killed and many others sickened from a poisoned water well in Masuubiye, Baidoa, Somalia. It is suspected that the well was poisoned by al Shabaab, a militant group affiliated with Al-Qaeda, in an attempt to prevent government soldiers from drinking the water.

Headline: Fight breaks out over access to water storage tank
Description: A fight breaks out between two militias over a dispute concerning an underground water storage tank.

Headline: Water for the Bari community, Somalia, cut off
Description: Water for the Bari community in Somalia is cut off during a violent confrontation between militants that reportedly support Islamic State and Puntland security forces.

Headline: Ethiopian troops reportedly attack a water source in Somalia
Description: Troops from Ethiopia reportedly attack a water source used by al Shabaab, leading to further fighting, in Bulo Burto, Hilraan, Somalia.

Headline: Two people killed in fight over control of water well, Somalia
Description: Two people are killed when local clans fight over control of a water point in Galkayo, Mudug, Somalia.

Headline: Gunfire exchanged during a water dispute
Description: Gunfire is exchanged between a soldier and a local resident due to a water dispute in Qandala, Bari, Somalia. Both parties are wounded.

Headline: One killed in dispute over access to a water well
Description: Two men from within the same clan get in a violent dispute over a well and the water supply in the village of Buundo Weyn, Beledweyne, Hiiraan, Somalia. One of the men shoots the other, killing him.

Headline: Conflict over water between two clans in Somalia kill at least 14 people
Description: A conflict between two clans that started over the use of water and pastureland leaves at least 14 people dead and 50 others injured in Garowe, Nugaal, Somalia. Sources differ on the number of dead and the date of the violent clash.

Headline: Demonstration over access to clean drinking water turns violent
Description: A demonstration led by locals from the northwest village of Moeka for clean drinking water turns violent. One protester is shot and killed and several homes are destroyed.

Headline: Protests over water shortages turn violent in South Africa
Description: Residents in South Africa protesting against water shortages are reported to have burned water tanks meant to help alleviate the problem.

Headline: Residents in a violent protest over water shortages in South Africa
Description: Residents of Msinga, Umzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, protesting against water shortages, block roads, target vehicles with stones, loot shops, and shoot at police.

Headline: Residents and police clash over lack of access to water in South Africa
Description: Residents of Bushbuckridge, Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga, South Africa, who claim to have asked for water for three years, stage a protest, including burning tires. Police respond to the protest, firing rubber bullets.

Headline: Illegal water connections contribute to fight between citizen groups, South Africa
Description: Two citizen groups fight two days in a row over allegedly illegal water and electricity connections in the City of Tshwane, Gauteng, South Africa.

Headline: Violence erupts during protests over lack of clean water in South Africa
Description: Residents protesting road conditions and lack of clean water are dispersed by police with teargas in Matatiele, Alfred Nzo, Eastern Cape, South Africa. The protest tactics were reported to include blocking roads with burning tires and large boulders.

Headline: Protest over water outages, power cuts, and fees turns violent
Description: Students lead a campus protest at a university over water outages, power cuts, and fees in Nkonkobe, Amathole, Eastern Cape, South Africa. The protest turns violent and the campus is shut down.

Headline: 38 killed; 30 injured in fighting over access to water and land in South Sudan
Description: According to a report, 38 people are killed and another 30 are injured in fighting between two local clans over water points, grazing land, and border areas, in Gogrial West, Warrap, South Sudan.

Headline: Violence between herdsmen and farmers over access to water and pasture
Description: Local militia allegedly supported by the Sudan People's Liberation Army attack Kenyan herdsmen who crossed the border in search of water and pasture for their cattle.

Headline: Violent clashes in South Sudan lead to 10 dead, many wounded, and destruction of a water point
Description: Violent clashes between government and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (SPLA-IO) cause the destruction of a water point and leave a reported 10 people dead and 16 more wounded in Wichok, Rubkona, Unity, South Sudan.

Headline: 11 injured in clashes between farmers and herdsmen over access to water
Description: Eleven people are injured after clashes between herdsmen over a water point in South Kordofan, Sudan.

Headline: Fighting between two clans in Sudan over ownership of water point leaves six dead
Description: Fighting between two clans near Lagawa, West Kordofan, Sudan over ownership of a water point leaves six dead and several others wounded.

Headline: Four people killed in clash over access to a water point in North Darfur, Sudan
Description: Former Sudan Liberation Army-Abdul Wahid (SLA-AW) rebels and Arab nomads clash over access to a water point in Kebkabiya, North Darfur, Sudan, resulting in the death of a total of four people from both sides of the conflict.

Headline: Protests over water outages turn violent in Sudan
Description: People protesting water outages are dispersed by police officers in Port Sudan, Red Sea, Sudan.

Headline: Civilians protesting lack of access to water are reportedly beaten and tortured
Description: Five people from a citizen water committee and local police in El Fasher, North Darfur, Sudan, are reportedly beaten and tortured by military officers after asking the military to allow local residents to organize and take water from a local source. Residents stage protests against the violent reaction of the military.
Sources: Sudanese Online 2017; Raleigh et al 2010 ID. 318554

Headline: Clashes in Darfur between farmers and herders over water access result in deaths
Description: At least 70 people have been killed in the past few months in clashes between farmers and herders over access to water resources and land in the southern part of Darfur.

Headline: ISIS floods villages in the Deir Hafer Plain of east Aleppo
Description: In response to the advance of the Syrian Arab Army, Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) floods villages they control in the Deir Hafer Plain of east Aleppo by pumping water from Lake Assad into the Al-Jar channel.

Headline: Attack on Islamic State forces controlling the Tabqa Dam
Description: A combined U.S. and Syrian force launches an attack in Syria on Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) forces controlling the Tabqa Dam, a "choke point" on the Euphrates River and source of hydroelectric power for the region, which has been under ISIL control. The bombs cause sever damage to the dam, stopping the flow of the river through it, threatening the integrity of the dam itself. Tens of thousands of civilians living below the dam are in immediate danger of complete destruction should the dam be overtopped.  Before the dam is overtopped, upstream dams in Turkey cut water flow while the Tabqa dam engineers, under watch by opposing forces, restore operation to the dam. Revelations about the attack in 2022 confirm the US's involvement, identifying US Special Operations unit Task Force 9 as the perpetrator of the attack, even though the dam was on the US military's "no-strike list."
Sources: Gibbons-Neff 2017; British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) 2017; Phillips, Khan, and Schmitt 2022

Headline: U.S. Coalition against the Islamic State destroys main pipeline to Raqqa
Description: The U.S.-led coalition against the Islamic State destroys the main pipeline supplying water to Raqqa. The official Syrian Arab News Agency says the pipeline was damaged in an airstrike.

Headline: Syrian forces regain control from the Islamic State over water treatment and pumping plants
Description: Syrian governmental forces and their allies regain control from the Islamic State of the water treatment and pumping plants for the strategic town of al Khafsa on the Euphrates River.

Headline: Protests over water cuts turn violent in Tunisia
Description: A long series of protests in July 2017 are reported associated with cuts in the distribution of drinking water. Buses are reportedly damaged by residents; citizens blockade a road; security forces and protesters are injured in confrontations.

Headline: Nearly 3 million people left without reliable access to water supplies in Ukraine
Description: A long series of attacks on energy and water systems in the Ukraine has intermittently left nearly three million people without access to reliable water supplies. This has included repeated damage to the Donetsk Filtration Plant, the South Donbas water pipeline, energy plants that supply power to water treatment and distribution systems, and the Carbonit Water Pumping Station.
Sources: ReliefWeb 2017b; UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) 2017; International Committee for the Red Cross (ICRC) 2017

Headline: Five killed; 11 injured in airstrikes on water systems in Yemen
Description: Airstrikes by coalition forces hits several water projects, killing five civilians and injuring 11 others in Saadah and Sahar, Sadah, Yemen.

Headline: Multi-day airstrikes in Yemen destroy water and electrical systems
Description: Airstrikes by coalition forces over a multi-day period hit water and electricity systems in Bajil and Al Hawak, Al Hudaydah, Yemen, killing one civilian.

Headline: Airstrikes in Yemen destroy water and electrical systems
Description: Airstrikes by coalition forces over a few days hit water and electricity systems in Sanaa and Taiz, Yemen.

Headline: Water and electrical systems in Yemen are attacked by coalition forces, killing two
Description: Two civilians in Maqbanah, Taiz, Yemen, are killed from airstrikes by coalition forces targeting water and electricity systems.

Headline: Demonstration over access to water and concerns about salary payments turn violent
Description: Citizens from Crater, Aden, Yemen, demonstrate to demand salary payments and access to water and electricity services by blocking roads and setting tires on fire.

Headline: Airstrikes in Jahran, Dhamar, Yemen hit water systems
Description: Airstrikes in Jahran, Dhamar, Yemen by coalition forces hit water and electricity systems.

Headline: Water and electrical systems in Yemen are attacked
Description: Airstrikes by coalition forces hit water and electricity systems in Sahar, Sadah, Yemen.

Headline: Power lines in Dhamar, Yemen are damaged, cutting water to over a million
Description: The power lines connected to a main water supply system in the city of Dhamar, Yemen are damaged by military activity, affecting approximately one million residents who rely on the water source.

Headline: Government forces in Yemen seize two major water wells; kill 12 Houthi
Description: Government forces seize two major water wells and kill 12 Houthi fighters in Sirwah, Marib, Yemen.

Headline: Multiple airstrikes hit a water storage facility, desalination plant, and other water infrastructure
Description: Multi-day airstrikes by coalition forces hit a water storage project, a desalination station, and other water infrastructure and electricity systems in Kamaran, Al Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Water tankers are destroyed in Yemen
Description: Al-Qaeda affiliated militants are reported to destroy multiple water tankers that belonged to Houthis militants and the Yemeni Army in Wald Rabi, Al Bayda,  and Lawdar, Abyan, Yemen.

Headline: Airstrike by coalition forces hits water and electric systems in Sanaa, Yemen
Description: An airstrike by coalition forces hits water and electricity stations in Al Kaniq, Hamdan, Sanaa, Yemen.

Headline: Airstrike by coalition forces hits water and electric systems in Hajjah, Yemen
Description: An airstrike by coalition forces hits water and electricity stations in Abs, Hajjah, Yemen.

Headline: Multiple coalition airstrikes against water and water systems in Yemen
Description: Coalition airstrikes target civilian infrastructure, including a water truck and a water pump, injuring at least one civilian in Al Azqul, Sahar, Sadah, and Al Irafaf, Damt, Ad Dali, Yemen.

Headline: Airstrikes, shelling and sniper attacks damage water structures in Al Mohka, Yemen
Description: Fighting in Yemen has damaged water infrastructure in several cities. Airstrikes, shelling, and sniper attacks in and around the town of Al Mokha have killed and injured scores of civilians and halted most services, including the main market and the water supply system.

Headline: Air raid damages water well in Yemen
Description: An air raid damages a water well in Nihm District, Sanaa, Yemen.

Headline: Al-Aqran dam is hit during three air raids in Yemen
Description: The Al-Aqran dam is hit during three air raids in Nihm District, Sanaa, Yemen.

Headline: Water and sewage treatment plants are attacked during air raids in Yemen
Description: Two water and sewage treatment plants in Hudaydah, Yemen are hit during air raids in Bajil and Al-Hawk Districts.

Headline: Water drill is hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water drill is hit during an air raid in Al-Safra'a District, Saada, Yemen.

Headline: Water project is bombed during air raid
Description: A water project is bombed during an air raid in Sihar District, Saada, Yemen.

Headline: Water project is hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water project is hit during an air raid in Hamdan District, Sanaa, Yemen.

Headline: Water truck is damaged by air raid in Yemen
Description: A water truck is damaged by an air raid in Al-Khawkhah District, Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Water truck is hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water truck is hit during an air raid in Harf Sufyan District, Amran, Yemen.

Headline: Water truck near a market is hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water truck is hit during an air raid near Hayran market, Hayran District, Hajjah, Yemen.

Headline: Water well and desalination plant are hit during air raids
Description: A water well and a desalination plant in Al Mokha District, Taizz, Yemen are hit during air raids.

Headline: Water well attacked in Yemen during air raids
Description: A water well is hit during air raids in Mawza District, Taizz, Yemen.

Headline: Well is hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: The Al-Naysani well in Maqbanah District, Taizz, Yemen is hit during an air raid.

Headline: Alleged support of Taliban by Iran, in part to disrupt water projects in Afghanistan
Description: Attacks to the city of Farah in the western region of Afghanistan in early 2018 by the Taliban may, in part, be supported by Iran in an attempt to reduce Afghanistan's ability to pursue water dam infrastructure projects. Experts disagree to the amount of support given to Taliban militants by Iran, but water projects in Afghanistan's western region are indisputably a point of contention between the two nations.
Sources: Hussein and Jedinia 2018; Jerusalem Post, The 2018

Headline: Protests in Algeria for improved water supply and electricity leads to clashes with police and injuries
Description: On July 22, residents of Ouargla, Algeria protest high electricity prices due to the heat wave and demand better access to tap water. Protesters clashed with police leading to several injuries. On September 15, protests expand and between 5,000 and 25,000 people demonstrate against inadequate water and sanitation infrastructure and a lack of jobs. This clash with police also leads to injuries.

Headline: A local water system is damaged in a shootout between drug trafficking gangs in Brazil
Description: On September 30, in Sao Goncalo, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil a shoot-out between drug trafficking gangs in the Minha Casa, Minda Vida complex of Joquei neighborhood damages the local water system, leaving residents without water.

Headline: An attempted theft of a water pump leads to an injury and arrest
Description: On August 21 in Campo Grande, Mato Grosso do Sul, Brazil a man is beaten after he tried to steal a water pump. The man was arrested.

Headline: A dispute over water used for local mining in Chile leads to a demonstration, clashes with police, and injuries
Description: On July 19, in Salamanca, Chile near Illapel (Coquimbo), around 60 residents of Cuncumen hold a demonstration calling for the end of water usage at the Los Pelambres mine. Police clash with demonstrators; eight injuries are reported.

Headline: Xiangyang, China residents protest water and air pollution and clashes with police lead to injuries and arrests
Description: On June 30, 2018, more than 1000 residents protest untreated wastewater discharge and groundwater contamination at a waste treatment plant in Xiangyang, China. Forty residents are arrested during clashes with local police; some residents are also injured and hospitalized.

Headline: An oil pipeline is attacked multiple times, causing oil to flow into a local waterway in Colombia
Description: On November 12, an oil pipeline is attacked four times in Arauca, Colombia, causing oil to flow into and pollute a nearby waterway. No group claims responsibility; however, sources attribute the attack to the National Liberation Army (ELN).
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201811110002, 201811110030, 201811120038

Headline: An explosive device detonates at an oil pipeline, causing oil to pollute a local waterway in Colombia
Description: On November 21, an oil pipeline is attacked in Boyaca, Colombia, polluting a local waterway with oil. No group claims responsibility; however, sources attribute the attack to the National Liberation Army (ELN).
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201811210002

Headline: Lack of access to potable water in the Dominican Republic leads to violent demonstrations
Description: On July 9, 2018, shots are fired at the police station in Navarrete, Villa Bisono, Dominican Republic during a violent demonstration to demand improved access to potable water.

Headline: One injury reported in protests in the Dominican Republic over access to potable water
Description: On August 1, a woman is injured by gunfire during a protest in Navarrete, Bisono, Dominican Republic to demand access to potable water.

Headline: A protest against a bill threatening water privatization in El Salvador is suppressed by government security forces
Description: On June 14, 2018, students from El Salvador University and affiliates to the National Administration for Water Supply and Sewerage march to the Legislative Assembly in San Salvador City to protest a water bill that they claim aims to privatize water. Security forces use teargas to disperse the protesters. One injury is reported.

Headline: More than 70 water systems damaged in Ethiopia related to violent conflicts
Description: At least 76 water systems have been damaged by the ongoing conflict in the Oromia region of Ethiopia. The larger conflict leading to these casualties is between different ethnic groups and has displaced hundreds of thousands of people.

Headline: Brothers murdered for opposing hydropower project in Guatemala
Description: Neri and Domingo Esteban Pedro were found murdered near the San Andres hydroelectric project on the Yal Witz River in western Guatemala. The brothers were vocal opponents of the project.

Headline: A hydroelectric plant in Guatemala is destroyed in a dispute over local water control
Description: On July 30, in Purulha, Baja Verapaz, Guatemala, community members occupy a hydroelectric plant, disarm local security, and destroy the infrastructure. The protestors claim that the hydroelectric plant is occupying lands of the community.

Headline: Water shortages in India lead to deadly fights between civilians and harassment of water company employees
Description: Lack of water in cities across India -- due to drought, growing populations, and inadequate infrastructure -- leads to high tensions, resulting in at least two deaths when a fight breaks out between residents waiting in line at a water truck. Those working for the water companies with the responsibility of turning different water lines on and off, called "key men," are increasingly harassed by residents wanting to persuade them to keep their water on.

Headline: Grenades are thrown and rounds are fired at a water pump house outside an Air Force post in India
Description: On February 20, grenades are thrown and rounds are fired at a water pump house outside an Air Force post in Malangpora, Jammu and Kashmir, India. No injuries are reported and no group claims the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201802200026

Headline: A water tanker is damaged in an attack on a construction site in India
Description: On March 2, a water tanker is damaged during an attack on a construction site near Kadambaguda, Odisha, India. One construction worker is kidnapped before being released a short time later.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201803020025

Headline: A water tanker is a casualty in one of seven attacks in Jharkhand, India on the same day
Description: On May 29, seven related attacks occur across Jharkhand, India. A water tanker is a casualty in one of the attacks. The Communist Party of India - Maoist is suspected as the group responsible for the attacks.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201805290033

Headline: A police station water tank is damaged in an attack on the station in India
Description: On June 27, assailants throw a grenade at a police station in Pulwama district, Jammu and Kashmir, India. No people are injured, however the station's water tank is damaged.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201806270018

Headline: A water tank and other farm items including cows are injured in an attack on a cowshed construction site in India
Description: On August 15, a water tank, a tractor, and motorbike are damaged and several cows are injured in an attack on a cowshed construction site in Bara, Bihar, India. The Communist Part of India - Maoist claim responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201808150052

Headline: Man shot over access to water in Delhi, India
Description: A man is shot in Sangam Vihar -- one of the poorest parts of Delhi -- during a dispute over water. The summer of 2018 sees one of the worst droughts in Dehli, India.

Headline: Father and son are beaten to death in water dispute in Delhi, India
Description: In Delhi during severe drought in 2018 a father and son are beaten to death in a water dispute.

Headline: A dispute over severe water shortage in the Hansi district of India leads to a clash causing a dozen injuries
Description: On June 26, a violent clash occurs between two villages, Puthi Mangal Khan and Dhani Peeranwali, in Hansi district, India over acute water shortages. At least 12 people are reported injured.

Headline: One death and several injuries are reported in a clash over wastewater drainage in India
Description: On October 29, a woman is killed and 7 others wounded in a clash over a waste water drainage in Sheharmalpur village (Panipat, Haryana), India.

Headline: Violence over irrigation water leads to at least one injury in India
Description: On November 16, in Singanapalle village in Banaganapalle tehsil (Kurnool, AP), India, local political parties clash with each other over water pipes. One person is injured and hospitalized.

Headline: A dispute over access to water leads to one injury in India
Description: On September 14, two families clash in Daria area of Chandigarh over getting water from a tap. A 17 year old girl was injured with a sickle in the fight.

Headline: Haryana, India villages clash over water, 12 injured
Description: Residents of one village in Haryana install a motor pump to draw water from a local water source, but residents of a nearby village object to it, leading to violent clashes, twelve injuries, and the destruction of the pump.

Headline: Injuries are reported when hundreds of students protest increases in water prices in Sulawesi, Indonesia
Description: On November 30, hundreds of students protest increases in water prices in Watampone district, South Sulawesi province, Indonesia. Two students are injured by unknown attackers.

Headline: Protests in Iran over lack of water, mismanagement, and corruption around water lead to deaths of dozens
Description: Ongoing protests against lack of water, mismanagement, and corruption around water are led by residents in small towns in western Iran. These protests gain more media attention as tensions escalate over time and may be linked to demonstrations from late 2017 and early 2018 that lead to the death of dozens of people. In 2018, at least nine environmental leaders are arrested, and one jailed environmentalist dies of alleged suicide.

Headline: Violent clashes between farmers and police over access to water leave one dead in Kazeroon, Iran
Description: One person is killed when police are sent to halt "illegal" water pumps Kazeroon, Iran, used by farmers and other villagers to access water.

Headline: Iranian security forces shoot at protesters, injuring one, at demonstration in Khorramshahr over lack of water
Description: Protests over lack of drinking water supplies in Khorramshahr, Iran begin in front of government buildings. Social media posts of these protests include sounds of shots and cries and show security forces shooting at protesters. Only one protester is reported injured.

Headline: Farmer injured in a clash with police in Varzaneh, Iran during a strike over access to water
Description: A farmer reports losing sight in one eye and wounds from a pellet gun from a clash with police ignited by a strike over lack of water in Varzaneh, Iran.

Headline: Protests over water shortages turn violent in Iran
Description: Water shortages in the southern part of Iran have caused protests, which turned violent with attacks on property and other infrastructure. Police action to break up the protests lead to several injuries and deaths.

Headline: Protests by farmers over transfers of water from Isfahan to Yazd, Iran turn violent and cause damage to water transfer systems
Description: Water systems used to transfer water from Isfahan to the neighboring province of Yazd are damaged multiple times by farmers protesting the loss of the water supply. Farmers blame the Iranian government for the lack of water in their region.  Reports from social media show police officers attacking farmers associated with the destroyed pipes.

Headline: Residents of Tall-e Kushk, Iran clash with police after water pumps are confiscated from well; one person is killed
Description: In July, residents of Tall-e Kushk, Iran clash with police, objecting to the confiscation of water pumps from the wells in the village. One person was killed after the police fired a warning shot to disperse the rioters.

Headline: Farmers in Qarneh, Iran destroy facilities diverting water from the city of Isfahan to neighboring Yazd province
Description: In mid-November, angry farmers in Qarneh demonstrate against farming water shortages and destroy facilities diverting water from the city of Isfahan to the neighboring Yazd Province, Iran. The security forces clash with the rioters.

Headline: Protests in Iran over water shortages and poor quality lead to injuries. Deaths also reported by some outlets
Description: In Iran, protests over the shortage and poor quality of drinking water turn violent as police open fire at rioters who throw stones and attack public buildings and banks. There are conflicting reports over the number of casualties; while Iranian officials deny any fatalities, they acknowledge that 11 people, including police officers, were wounded. Opposition websites report up to 4 fatalities among the demonstrators.

Headline: Iraqi female activist assassinated
Description: An Iraqi activist, Su?ad Al-Ali, is assassinated while getting into her vehicle in Basra, Iraq. Mrs. Al-Ali had worked to bring better government services to her community, including safe and reliable drinking water.

Headline: Tens of thousands admitted to hospitals from contaminated drinking water, inciting violence that leads to deaths and injuries
Description: Tens of thousands fall ill from contaminated drinking water in Basra, Iraq. In response, citizen unrest escalates and protests turn violent, leaving at least 15 dead and hundreds injured.

Headline: A water project is attacked with explosive devices in Iraq
Description: On October 4, a water project in Gharib, Kirkuk, Iraq is targeted and attacked with explosive devices. No group claims responsibility for the attack; however, sources attribute the attack to the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL).
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201810040002

Headline: Government employees repairing a water pipeline are attacked in Iraq
Description: On October 5, government employees from the Ministry of Transportation who are repairing a water pipeline are attacked in Shatt al-Arab, Basra, Iraq. No group claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201810060039

Headline: Explosives detonate at a water plant in Iraq
Description: On October 6, explosives detonate at a water plant in Abbasi, Kirkuk, Iraq. No group claims responsibility for the attack; however, sources attribute the attack to the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL).
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201810060046

Headline: Protests against poor water quality and services in Iraq lead to one death and several injuries
Description: On July 10, hundreds of citizens in Al-Haritha, north of Basra, Iraq block a road in protest against poor services and the salinity of the water. One demonstrator is killed and several wounded.

Headline: Water coolers at a mosque are poisoned in Iraq
Description: On December 5, an unknown assailant poisons water coolers at a mosque in Nasiriyah, Dhi Qar, Iraq.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201812050004

Headline: Conflicts over pasture land and water resources lead to violence
Description: 14 people are killed in Northern Kenya, near Marsabit, after ongoing conflicts between two ethnic groups over land and water resources turns violent.

Headline: Two groups clash at the water plant in Muranga, Kenya, with damage to the water supply system
Description: On August 27th, two groups clash at the water plant in Muranga, Kenya, with one group damaging the water supply at the plant.

Headline: Clashes expand between Tajik and Kyrgyz farmers over irrigation water
Description: Clashes between farmers over irrigation water across the Tajikistan-Kyrgyzstan border escalate, with at least two instances involving armed guards to defuse the fights. One fight started over the installation of a water pump.

Headline: Water project is attached and workers are killed and kidnapped by suspected militant group in Libya
Description: In July 2018, Daesh militants are suspected of two attacks to workers of the Great Man-made River, a large water supply project that transports water from the Sahara desert to communities and agricultural fields in northern Libya. During the first attack four technicians from the Al-Hassouna plant are kidnapped, but later released. During the second attack two workers are killed and two guards are kidnapped.
Sources: OOSKANews Correspondent 2018; Raleigh et al 2010 ID. 6743748

Headline: Four water wells are attacked in Libya
Description: On December 9, four water wells are attacked in Libya. No group claims responsibility for the attacks.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201812090005, 201812090006, 201812090007

Headline: Workers at a pumping station in Libya are threatened by attackers with firearms
Description: On December 18, attackers with firearms enter the Hasawneh pumping station and threaten workers in Jafara, Libya. No casualties are reported but valuables are stolen during the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201812180008

Headline: Islamic State militants attack the Sarir water station in Libya and clash with government forces
Description: In August, Libyan government forces clash with Islamic State militants near Haruj following an attack on the Sarir water station.
Sources: Raleigh et al 2010 ID. 6738502; National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201808130008

Headline: At least 8 more killed in ongoing conflict over access to water between farmers and herders, Mali
Description: At least eight more people die in an ongoing conflict between the Fulani and Dogon communities in Mali near the town of Koro, sparked by access to water and grazing disputes. Since March 2018, the total death toll from this ongoing conflict is reported to be 25.

Headline: Mexican farmers and white landowners clash over water
Description: An alliance of local Mexican farmers storm the property of a white family living in Chihuahua state, Mexico, in frustration over what the farmers believe is an excessive use of water from the local river and aquifer. The clash results in one farmer being shot and other injuries to individuals on both sides of the conflict.

Headline: Two killed while protecting water rights in Mexico
Description: A father and son, Ramon Hernandez Nevarez and Anselmo Hernandez Andujo, are murdered while traveling together in Namiquipa, Chihuaua, Mexico. The two were farmers and known locally as water defenders, working to protect the Carmen River from over exploitation. The murderers have not been identified, however, it is thought that they were killed by people from an armed cartel called "La Linea."

Headline: Two men receive death threats for fighting against water wells in Chihuahua, Mexico
Description: Two men, Martin Solis Bustamente and Eraclio Rodriguez, receive death threats for fighting what they see as the illegal construction and operation of water wells in the Carmen River Basin, Chihuahua, Mexico.

Headline: Prison inmates in Campeche, Mexico riot to protest lack of drinking water Two injuries are reported
Description: On October 24, inmates of the San Francisco Koben Social Reintegration Center, Campeche, Mexico demonstrate against the lack of drinking water supply. They clash with the Penitentiary Police for about two hours until the Campeche State Undersecretary of Public Security mediates the riot. Two injuries are reported.

Headline: A large number of deaths are reported in attack on farmers by armed herdsmen in Nigeria over water and land resources
Description: On a single day in Nigeria's Plateau state, an attack by armed herdsmen leaves dozens in farming communities dead. This attack is part of ongoing violence that is in part triggered by access to water and land resources. Reports vary in the number dead; one cites 200 and another, 86.
Sources: Agence France-Presse (AFP) 2018b; Reuters 2018; McNeill and Akwagyiram 2018

Headline: 11 deaths attributed to ongoing conflict between herdsmen and farmers
Description: Eleven are killed and 11 more injured during an attack by Fulani herdsmen on a farming community in Central Nigeria, ignited by the continuing conflict over land and water resources.

Headline: A fight over the distribution of irrigation water in Pakistan injures seven
Description: On August 18, two groups of the Bozdar tribe clash over distribution of irrigation water in Pir Barhi village, Sindh, Pakistan using sticks, rocks, and guns. Seven people are injured and hospitalized and one person arrested.

Headline: Seven people are hospitalized after a fight over sewage water in Pakistan
Description: Neighbors clash over the issue of sewage water in the street in Gujranwala City, Pakistan on Aug 16. Seven people are hospitalized.

Headline: Clans in Pakistan clash over water supply, killing one and injuring four
Description: Machi and Wadhayo clans clash over water supply and agricultural lands on June 23 in Pakistan. A youth is killed and 4 others are injured.

Headline: A fight over irrigation water in Pakistan kills two villagers and injures three more
Description: On September 23, the Lanjar and Chandio tribes clash over irrigation water near Moro city (Naushahro Feroze, Sindh). Two villagers are killed and three are injured.

Headline: A dispute over water distribution in Shikarpur, Pakistan leads to more than two dozen injuries
Description: On July 15, 26 men sustain critical injuries in a clash between two groups of Sethar community in Batro area, Shikarpur, Pakistan over water distribution.

Headline: Seven people injured during dispute over irrigation water in Pakistan
Description: Two groups in Jaffarabad District of Balochistan, Pakistan clash over an irrigation water dispute on June 25. Seven people are injured.

Headline: A fight over water drainage in Pakistan kills one person
Description: On September 23, two groups of the Kalhoro community clash over water drainage issues in Kholar, Sindh, Pakistan, killing one man.

Headline: One injury is reported when Israeli forces destroy a water pipeline in Palestine
Description: On October 13, Israeli forces destroy a water pipeline in Kafr Qaddum sparking clashes with locals. An elderly woman is reportedly injured when she is hit with a tear gas canister.

Headline: A demonstration against the lack of water supply in Talara, Peru results in two injuries
Description: On October 1, in Talara, Piura, Peru, hundreds of local inhabitants demonstrate against the lack of water supply in the area. Police clash with demonstrators by shooting rubber bullets and throwing tear gas, injuring two rioters.

Headline: Al Shabaab diverts a river, forcing opposition to undefendable higher ground in Somalia
Description: Al Shabaab, a group fighting to create an Islamic state in Somalia, diverts water from the Jubba River, causing a flood that forced Somali, Kenyan, and U.S. military forces to move to higher ground where they were later ambushed. One soldier from the U.S. was killed in the ambush.

Headline: A well is damaged in an attack on Kenya Defense Forces in Somalia
Description: On July 27, in an attack on Kenya Defense Forces soldiers in Dhamaso, Gedo, Somalia, a well and telecommunications equipment are damaged. No group claims responsibility for the incident; however, sources attribute the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201807270003

Headline: Violence breaks out at a line waiting for water at a spring in Cape Town
Description: Violence breaks out at a line waiting for water at a spring in a neighborhood in Cape Town after severe drought leaves the city with dwindling water supplies. After restrictions were imposed in early 2018, citizens have taken to collecting water from local springs, which are not counted in their water restrictions. In response to this violence, guards are posted at the spring and restrictions put on how much water can be collected.

Headline: Protests over water and electric services in South Africa turn violent and leave one police officer injured
Description: On June 30, Dube Village residents block a highway, burn tires, and throw stones at the police demanding service delivery of water and electricity from eThekwini Municipality in Inanda. A police officer is injured during the protest.

Headline: A UN mission collecting water for their base in South Sudan is attacked, injuring one Nepalese peacekeeper
Description: On September 15th, an officer with the National Security Service of South Sudan fires at an UNMISS convoy collecting water for the UNMISS base in Yei, wounding a Nepalese peacekeeper.

Headline: Water infrastructure attacked in Syria
Description: Water infrastructure are attacked, along with health centers and hospitals, in an offensive by Turkey in the Afrin and Tal Rifaat districts in Syria.

Headline: Major dam and water source captured in Syria
Description: The Afrin Dam, a major dam and water source on the Afrin River in Syria, is captured by Turkish forces and their Syrian militia allies, causing concern for the nearby communities that depend on the dam for water. These same forces are also in control of nearby Maydanki dam. Interruptions to water and electricity in communities dependent on these dams have occurred, along with reports of attacks on civilian centers and populations.

Headline: A truck carrying water tanks is used by suicide bombers in a failed attack in Syria
Description: On January 18, a group of suicide bombers using a truck carrying water tanks in Aleppo, Syria is stopped by the Free Syrian Army. Members of the FSA kill three of the assailants and a fourth dies when he detonates his explosive device.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201801180025

Headline: A fight over a water point in Syria between government militias and Islamic State fighters results in multiple deaths
Description: Regime and loyalist militia forces including Hezbollah clash with Islamic State fighters in the Tlul al Safa area of Syria over an important water point. Regime air and missile strikes kill at least four Islamic State fighters and an estimated 10 others.

Headline: One killed and several injured in fighting between farmers and herders in Tanzania over access to water
Description: One person is killed and several police officers are injured in a fight over access to water resources between herders and farmers near the village of Dihida, Morogoro, Tanzania.

Headline: Of 18 related violent attacks in one day in Thailand, one occurs at a waterworks authority compound
Description: On May 20, 18 related violent attacks occur across Thailand. One of the 18 occurs at a Provincial Waterworks authority compound in Bacho, Narathiwat. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however, the Barisan Revolusi Nasional are thought to be responsible.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201805200020

Headline: The Donetsk Filter Station is attacked, affecting water supply to 350,000
Description: Damage to the Donetsk Filter Station from shelling as well as gunfire directed at water station staff affects the reliability of water supply to approximately 350,000 people. This event is related to previous disruptions in water services from similar attacks in 2017.
Sources: Dymkovskyy 2018; UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) 2018b

Headline: Attacks on water infrastructure in the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine cause water shortages for millions
Description: Water shortages are reported by residents living in at least 20 communities near the line of conflict in the Donbass region of Ukraine. In spite of a ceasefire negotiated in 2014, the ongoing violence has damaged public utilities, leaving millions of residents without water for days and weeks at a time.
Sources: REACH 2018; Protection Cluster 2018; Strategic Foresight Group 2019

Headline: Water company truck hits landmine on the way to repair water pipes in Ukraine, injuring two
Description: A water company truck driven by two employees strikes a land mine on its way to an emergency repair of damages to a water pipe due to attacks. Two water utility employees are injured. The water pipe services approximately 45,000 people with water.
Sources: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) 2018a

Headline: A water filtration vehicle is attacked in Ukraine, five employees are injured
Description: On April 17, a water filtration vehicle is attacked in Donetsk, Ukraine. At least five employees are injured.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201804170026

Headline: Over 230 people are sickened by poisoned drinking water in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia
Description: Over 230 people are poisoned through contaminated drinking water in the town of Makiivka in the Donetsk region Ukraine. That water is thought to have been intentionally contaminated.

Headline: Protest to prevent oil pipeline that threatens water resources is met with violent arrests
Description: Dozens of protestors are arrested and restrained, sometimes with violent tactics, as they physically resist the construction of a major oil pipeline. The protestors argue that the pipeline is proceeding illegally and that it threatens their water supplies as well as other resources that are vital to their way of life.
Sources: L'eau Est La Vie Camp 2018; Zanolli 2018; Jamail 2018

Headline: Two are injured during protests over water services in Miranda, Venezuela
Description: On August 16, in Los Teques, Miranda, Venezuela a group of people build barricades using burning tires and garbage bags to protest problems with water services. The riots turn more violent when a group of people clash with the municipal police with firearms. Two police officers are injured. The police arrest a group of rioters.

Headline: Injuries are reported during protests to demand potable water, food, and energy in Lara state, Venezuela
Description: On December 17, in the Palavecino municipality in Lara state, Venezuela residents from several communities protest to demand the distribution of food, domestic gas, and potable water. State police officers use force against protesters by shooting pellets and tear gas to disperse the protest. Pregnant women and the elderly are reportedly beaten by police officers.

Headline: One person is killed during a protest in Bolivar state, Venezuela to demand potable water and electricity
Description: On July 16, one person is killed in San Felix, Ciudad Guayana, Bolivar state, Venezuela during a protest to demand potable water and electric power in the city.

Headline: A water well and other structures are damaged by airstrike
Description: Five farmers are killed in an airstrike while getting water from a pump in Al-Jah in Bayt Al-Faqih, Yemen. The water well, a mosque, and houses are damaged in the airstrike.

Headline: Airstrike targets a water-transport truck in Yemen
Description: A young girl is seriously injured by a Saudi-led coalition airstrike that targeted a water-transport truck in Ad Dhahi area of Hudayda, Yemen.

Headline: Airstrike targets a water project in Yemen
Description: A Saudi-led coalition airstrike targets a water project in the al-Hamzat area of Sahar district, Yemen.

Headline: Pro-Hadi forces manage to take a water project
Description: Pro-Hadi forces manage to take a number of sites after clashing with Houthi militias in the Alb area of Sadah, Yemen. According to the source, pro-Hadi troops take the areas of Mimna, Dhaher al-Burkan, Al Masirah, Water project, Al-Faridh, Qiraa'a, and the sniper outpost, all in the Alb area. No information on casualties.

Headline: Pro-Houthi forces reportedly destroy water collection tanks
Description: Property destruction: Pro-Houthi forces reportedly destroy water collection tanks in Bani Zuhayr village west of Hays city in the south of Al Hudaydah Governorate. The tanks are reportedly the only source of water for the citizens of Hays district.

Headline: Air raid targets a water tanker
Description: A Saudi-led coalition air raid is reported on Al Ghawl area of Nihm district, northeast of Sanaa city, allegedly targeting a water tanker. No casualties are reported.

Headline: Air raids are reported on a water rig
Description: Two Saudi-led coalition air raids are reported on a water rig in Al Ammar area of Sadah border Governorate in northwestern Yemen. No casualties are reported.

Headline: Water well digging machine is destroyed by airstrikes
Description: In Sadah, Yemen, a civilian is injured and a water well digging machine is destroyed by 5 Saudi-led coalition airstrikes that hit in Farwah and Mahather areas of Sahar district.

Headline: Pro-Houthi forces reportedly blow up a water tank
Description: Pro-Houthi forces reportedly blow up the main water tank of Tuhayta as anti-Houthi forces are closing in on the city.

Headline: Airstrike hits a water project in Yemen
Description: A Saudi-led coalition airstrike reportedly hits a water project in the Nushur area of Safra district, threatening to affect up to 10,500 people who rely on the water supplied by the project in Yemen. No injuries or fatalities are reported. This particular project has been hit three times by airstrikes.

Headline: Main water tank is targeted by military shelling
Description: The main water tank of Durayhimi district, Yemen, which supplies most of the district in drinking water, is reportedly targeted by military shelling. Conflicting reports from local sources attribute the bombing to either pro-Houthi forces or Saudi-led coalition Apache helicopters that are targeting Houthi snipers near the tank. No casualties are reported.

Headline: Air raids are reported on water wells and reservoirs in Yemen
Description: Five Saudi-led coalition air raids are reported on water wells and reservoirs across the Kamaran island in the north of Hudaydah Governorate, western Yemen. No casualties are reported but a large number of wells and reservoirs are destroyed.

Headline: Two people are killed because of a dispute over a watercourse
Description: Two people are killed and another is injured as a result of a tribal dispute over a watercourse in Bait Al-Hadi Village, Al-Qiblah, Ar Rujum District, Al-Mahwit Governorate, Yemen.

Headline: Clashes between tribesmen and pro-Houthi force over a water project
Description: For the second consecutive day, clashes between Al 'Ukad tribesmen and pro-Houthi forces are reported in the Ridmah district of Ibb Governorate, Yemen. Clashes are reportedly initiated on September 24 as the tribesmen seize the weapons of a group of Houthi fighters to show their opposition to a water project. Injuries are reported on both sides but no fatalities.

Headline: Tank used to store water is by an airstrike
Description: A tank used to store potable water is hit by a Saudi coalition airstrike in Kamaran district, Yemen.

Headline: Two airstrikes hit a water dam
Description: The Saudi-led coalition launches two airstrikes at Houthi forces in the Al Wahabiyah area in Al Sawadiyah district, Al Bayda Governorate, Yemen, hitting a water dam and killing a number of Houthi fighters.

Headline: Airstrikes damage water and sanitation infrastructure in Yemen
Description: Airstrikes over several days in July in the city of Al-Hudaydah, Yemen, damage water and sanitation infrastructure, including many drinking water wells.

Headline: Desalination plant is hit during air raids in Yemen
Description: A desalination plant in Hays District, Hudayah, Yemen is hit during air raids.

Headline: Water driller is hit during air raids
Description: A water driller is hit during multiple air raids in Sihar District, Saada, Yemen.

Headline: Water drilling equipment is hit during air in Yemen
Description: A water drill is hit during an air raid in Sihar District, Saada, Yemen.

Headline: Water fountain is damaged in air raid
Description: A water fountain in Haydan District, Saada, Yemen is damaged in an air raid.

Headline: Water project is bombed during air raid
Description: A water project is bombed during an air raid in Sihar District, Saada, Yemen.

Headline: Well is damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A water well in Al-Silw District, Taizz is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Well is damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A water well in Hays District, Hudaydah is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Desalination plant hit during air raids in Yemen
Description: A desalination plant in Hays District, Hudayah, Yemen is hit during air raids.

Headline: Sanitation facility damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A sanitation facility in Zabid District, Hudaydah is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Water dam hit during air raids
Description: A water dam is hit during multiple air raids in Al-Sawadiyah District, Bayda, Yemen.

Headline: Water driller damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A water driller in Baqim District, Saada is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Water driller hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water driller is hit during an air raid in Majz District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Water driller hit during air raid
Description: A water driller is hit during an air raid in Al-Dhuha district, Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Water driller hit during air raids
Description: A water driller is hit during multiple air raids in Sihar District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Water fountain damaged in air raid
Description: A water fountain in Haydan District, Sa'ada, Yemen is damaged in an air raid.

Headline: Water project hit during air raid
Description: A water project is hit during an air raid in Sihar District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Water project hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: A water project is hit during an air raid in Al-Safra'a District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Water pump hit during air raid
Description: A water pump is hit during an air raid in Sihar District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Water tank hit during air raid
Description: A water tank is hit during an air raid in Haydan District, Sa'ada, Yemen.

Headline: Water tank hit during air raid in Yemen
Description: On December 10, a water tank is hit during an air raid in Kamaran District, Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Water tank is damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A water tank in Al-Durayhimi District, Hudaydah is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Water well hit during air raid
Description: On October 10, a water well is hit during an air raid in Bait Al-Faqih District, Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Water wells hit during air raids
Description: Water wells are hit during multiple air raids in Kamaran, Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Water wells project hit during air raids
Description: A water wells project is hit during multiple air raids in Al-Hudaydah city, Al-Hudaydah, Yemen.

Headline: Well damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A water well in Al-Silw District, Taizz is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Well damaged in conflict in Yemen
Description: A water well in Hays District, Hudaydah is damaged in the ongoing conflict in Yemen.

Headline: Clashes over a water project in Yemen result in injuries
Description: Clashes between Al 'Ukad tribesmen and pro-Houthi forces are reported in the Ridmah district of Ibb governorate, Yemen, over opposition to a water project. Injuries are reported on both sides.

Headline: Clashes in Yemen between pro- and anti-Houthi forces result in many deaths and injuries and the destruction of water tanks at the Al-Thawrah hospital
Description: On November 11, fierce clashes between pro-Houthi and anti-Houthi National Resistance forces are reported in the direct vicinity of Al-Thawrah hospital in the south of Hodeidah city, resulting in damages to the building, including the destruction of its water tanks, and the injuring of many patients as they evacuated the hospital. On November 12, medics in hospitals across the city reported the death of 110 pro-Houthi fighters, 32 anti-Houthi fighters and 7 civilians over a 24-hour period.

Headline: Deaths are reported in protests over a mine that would contaminate local water sources in Honduras
Description: Beginning in 2011, members of the community of El Guapinol, Honduras, protest the development of an open-pit mine that would contaminate their water source, the Guapinol River. In 2018, the group protesting set up an encampment that after several months is violently broken up by security guards. One protestor is shot and killed and others are arrested and put in jail. In October, 2020, another member of the community who participates in the protests is shot and killed in his own home.

Headline: Violence in western Ethiopia, in part driven by shortages of water and land resources, displaces one million people
Description: Violence in western Ethiopia displaces one million people. The violence is in part driven by shortages of water and land resources.

Headline: War and soaring temperatures leave women and children water collectors vulnerable in South Sudan
Description: War and soaring temperatures leave many rural communities in South Sudan with little or no local water sources. Women and children are subjected to violent attacks, rape, and murder when traveling to regional sources to collect water. Leaders report conflicts sparked by water shortages occurring between the many of the 60 different ethnic groups across the country.

Headline: Two are killed and one injured when an explosive device detonates targeting police transporting water in Afghanistan
Description: On July 13, a explosive device targeting a police truck transporting water detonates, killing two and injuring one in Miya Nishin district, Kandahar, Afghanistan. No group claim responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201907130028

Headline: A water tank and windows are damaged during an attack on a polling center in Afghanistan
Description: On September 28, a water tank and several windows are damaged during an attack on a polling center in a female high school in Fayzabad, Jawzjan, Afghanistan. The Taliban claims responsibility for the attack.
Sources: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) 2019 ID. 201909280054

Headline: Afghan police attack Taliban militants trying to destroy a water well; seven deaths are reported
Description: As reported on August 9, Afghan police forces attack Taliban militants trying to destroy a water well in Almar district, Faryab. Seven militants are killed and nine are wounded.

Headline: Local residents in Mat, Albania clash with police over the construction of a hydroelectric plant
Description: On October 26, residents of Zall Gjocaj village in Mat, Albania clash with police while demonstrating against the construction of a hydroelectric power station. The residents are worried about local water supply.

Headline: One farmer is killed and three others injured in armed clash over access to water in Bangladesh
Description: On March 16, a farmer is stabbed and killed and three others injured in an armed clash between two groups of villagers at Dhaki village, Mithamain, Bangladesh over a water body dispute.

Headline: At least 50 people are injured in Bangladesh in a dispute over a local water body
Description: On August 6, at least 50 people are injured in a clash between two groups of villagers at Modhurapur village, Bangladesh over a local water body. Police fire tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

Headline: One death is reported in an armed clash over control of water in Bangladesh
Description: On August 21, an eight-year old boy is killed in an armed clash between two groups over the control of water body in Kulaura Upazila, Maulvibazar, Bangladesh.
